Compared to marine source rocks, lacustrine source rocks are more susceptible to events such as volcanic activity, hydrothermal action, and transgression. Furthermore, transgression has a significant impact on the development of hydrocarbon source rocks, promoting the enrichment and preservation of organic matter(Cullers, 2000; Hu et al., 2020; Li et al., 2017). Notable research progress has been made in various regions, including the Songliao Basin, Bohai Bay Basin, Subei Basin, and South Yellow Sea Basin in China, as well as the Otway Basin in Australia, East Niger Basin in southeastern Niger, Central Europe Basin, and South and Central Sumatra Basin in Indonesia. Transgression events tend to favor the accumulation of organic matter and contribute to the formation of organic-rich shale(Chen et al., 2020; Tsikopoulou et al., 2019; Xiao et al., 2021; Zhao et al., 2021).. In the Subei Basin of East China, the Early Paleocene Funing Formation consists of fine-grained sedimentary rocks rich in organic matter. These rocks have become a target for oil and gas exploration and development (Liu et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2022). Previous studies have indicated that the lacustrine source rocks of the Funing Formation developed under the combined influence of transgression and paleoclimate warming. The accumulation of organic matter is primarily regulated by these factors, as well as the anoxic conditions of saltwater. However, a detailed investigation of the sources of organic matter and the evolution of the sedimentary environment in the Funing Formation is still lacking.

Compared to marine source rocks, lacustrine source rocks are more susceptible to events such as volcanic activity, hydrothermal action, and transgression (Lacustrine source rocks are more susceptible to events such as volcanic activity, hydrothermal action, and transgression compared to marine source rocks). Transgression significantly impacts the development of hydrocarbon source rocks, promoting the enrichment and preservation of organic matter (Cullers, 2000; Hu et al., 2020; Li et al., 2017). Notable research progress has been made in various regions, including China (Songliao Basin, Bohai Bay Basin, Subei Basin, and South Yellow Sea Basin), Australia (Otway Basin), southeast Niger (East Niger Basin), Europe (Central Europe Basin), and Indonesia (South and Central Sumatra Basin). Transgression events favor the accumulation of organic matter and contribute to the formation of organic-rich shale (Chen et al., 2020; Tsikopoulou et al., 2019; Xiao et al., 2021; Zhao et al., 2021). In the Subei Basin of East China, the Early Paleocene Funing Formation consists of fine-grained sedimentary rocks rich in organic matter. These rocks have become targets for oil and gas exploration and development (Liu et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2022). Previous studies have indicated that the lacustrine source rocks of the Funing Formation developed under the combined influence of transgression and paleoclimate warming (Liu et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2022). The accumulation of organic matter is primarily regulated by these factors and the anoxic conditions of saltwater. However, a detailed investigation of the sources of organic matter and the evolution of the sedimentary environment in the Funing Formation is still lacking.

Jiangsu and Anhui provinces share a border with the Subei Basin, which spans an area of approximately 3.6×104 km2 and extends towards the Yellow Sea. Within the Subei Basin, several oil and gas fields have been discovered with the Funing Formation serving as the source rock. The Subei Basin originated during the Late Cretaceous period (Fig.1a)(Cheng et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2020). The structural framework of the Subei Basin comprises two depressions flanking an uplift, as illustrated in Figure 1b. Each depression can be further subdivided into multiple protrusions and depressions. The Haian sag is situated in the Dongtai sag, southeast of the Qintong sag, and neighboring the Yellow Sea to the west in the northeast. It is also adjacent to the Tongyang uplift in the south and the Baiju sag in the north. The Haian sag consists of seven secondary sags and one uplift. The specific distribution of the secondary sags is depicted in Fig. 1c (Liu et al., 2021). The southern region of the Haian sag is a crucial area for shale oil exploration and development, with the Qutang sub-sag holding significant potential for oil resources. The Qutang sub-sag encompasses the Taizhou Formation, Funing Formation, Dainan Formation, and Sanduo Formation. Within the Qutang sub-sag, the Funing Formation is divided into four members from bottom to top. Due to the influence of the depositional environment, the bottom section of the second member of the Funing Formation is characterized by the development of argillaceous dolomite and dolomitic shale, while the middle member features calcareous shale. The upper section, in comparison to the dolomitic shale, exhibits higher clay contents and a relatively tranquil water environment. The lithological composition displays significant vertical heterogeneity. Based on sequence characteristics, it can be further subdivided into three subsequences (Fig. 2).

The Subei Basin originated during the Late Cretaceous period according to previous studies (Cheng et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2020) as shown in Figure 1a. The Subei Basin is characterized by a structural framework consisting of two depressions flanking an uplift, as illustrated in Figure 1b. Further subdivision of each depression reveals multiple protrusions and depressions within the Subei Basin. The Haian sag is located in the Dongtai sag, situated to the southeast of the Qintong sag, and adjacent to the Yellow Sea on the west side. Additionally, it is adjacent to the Tongyang uplift in the south and the Baiju sag in the north. The Haian sag is comprised of seven secondary sags and one uplift. Fig. 1c (Liu et al., 2021) illustrates the specific distribution of the secondary sags. The southern region of the Haian sag, particularly the Qutang sub-sag, is an essential area for shale oil exploration and development due to its significant potential for oil resources. The Qutang sub-sag comprises the Taizhou Formation, Funing Formation, Dainan Formation, and Sanduo Formation. The Funing Formation within the Qutang sub-sag is divided into four members, ordered from bottom to top. The bottom section of the second member of the Funing Formation is characterized by the development of argillaceous dolomite and dolomitic shale, while the middle member is dominated by calcareous shale, attributed to the influence of the depositional environment. Contrasting with the dolomitic shale, the upper section exhibits higher clay contents and indicates a relatively tranquil water environment. The lithological composition exhibits notable vertical heterogeneity. Three subsequences can be further identified based on sequence characteristics (Fig. 2).

To conduct a comprehensive analysis of the sedimentary environment and its influence on organic matter, a total of 37 samples were collected from Well A1, as illustrated in Fig. 2. The core lithology predominantly consists of shale, spanning a depth range of 3808.24-4052.00m.
Sample analysis was conducted at China University of Petroleum (Beijing). The 37 samples underwent various analytical techniques, including XRD (X-ray diffraction), thin section analysis, SEM (scanning electron microscopy) observations, TOC (total organic carbon) measurements, pyrolysis experiments, saturated hydrocarbon chromatographic analysis, as well as trace element and isotope analysis. An Agilent 6890 Gas Chromatograph (GC) fitted with an HP-5MS column (30-m 0.25-mm, with 0.25-m film thickness) and connected to an Agilent 5975i Mass Spectrometer was used to analyze the molecular biomarkers in the aliphatic fraction (MS).

In order to comprehensively analyze the sedimentary environment and its impact on organic matter, a total of 37 samples were collected from Well A1, as depicted in Figure 2. The core lithology primarily comprises shale and extends to a depth range of 3808.24-4052.00m. The sample analysis took place at China University of Petroleum (Beijing). Various analytical techniques were applied to analyze the 37 samples, including XRD (X-ray diffraction), thin section analysis, SEM (scanning electron microscopy) observations, TOC (total organic carbon) measurements, pyrolysis experiments, saturated hydrocarbon chromatographic analysis, as well as trace element and isotope analysis. The molecular biomarkers in the aliphatic fraction (MS) were analyzed using an Agilent 6890 Gas Chromatograph (GC) equipped with an HP-5MS column (30-m 0.25-mm, with 0.25-m film thickness) and connected to an Agilent 5975i Mass Spectrometer.

The mineralogical analysis results of the shale samples are presented in Fig. 3. The predominant mineral components in the E1f2 shale samples include quartz, feldspar, clay (mainly chlorite and illite), calcite, and dolomite. The samples exhibit a high clay content, with noticeable vertical heterogeneity in mineral composition. Based on the classification of shale lithofacies, the shale of the second member of the Funing Formation primarily consists of mixed shale, argillaceous shale, and calcareous shale.

Figure 3 displays the results of the mineralogical analysis conducted on the shale samples. The E1f2 shale samples are mainly composed of quartz, feldspar, clay minerals (primarily chlorite and illite), as well as calcite and dolomite. The samples demonstrate a substantial clay content and exhibit noticeable vertical heterogeneity in terms of mineral composition. According to the classification of shale lithofacies, the shale of the second member of the Funing Formation primarily belongs to mixed shale, argillaceous shale, and calcareous shale categories.

Organic matter in source rocks is essential for hydrocarbon production, and its quantity is a key determinant of the rocks’ ability to generate hydrocarbons (Ekoko et al., 2022; Kuang et al., 2022). To assess the organic matter content, geochemical parameters such as Total Organic Carbon (TOC), sum of hydrocarbon genetic potential (S1+S2), chloroform asphalt “A,” and Hydrocarbon Index (HI) are commonly used. The lacustrine shale of the Funing Formation, due to its high degree of thermal evolution reaching an advanced overmature stage, contains a reduced concentration of chloroform bitumen “A” and has limited hydrocarbon potential. However, the abundance of lacustrine shale in the Funing Formation, with significant organic matter content, conforms to the criteria for “good” or “excellent” source rocks (Fig. 4).

Based on the analysis results of organic matter carbon isotopes, biomarker compounds and trace elements, it was found that the depositional environment of lacustrine shale in the study area is obviously different, and the sources of organic matter are different (Fig. 11). During the Sq3 period, the study area was a dry and saline closed lake basin, and regular steranes and carbon isotopes together reflected that the organic matter parent material was mainly derived from terrestrial higher plants. During the Sq2 period, Gammacerane/(Gammacerane+C30Hopane) indicates that marine transgression occurred in the study area, carrying a large amount of nutrients, and carbon isotopes indicate that plankton is the dominant species, with local contributions from higher plants. During the Sq1 period, C27⁃C28⁃C29 regular steranes and rearranged steranes as well as carbon isotopes indicate the contribution of organic matter from plankton.

Rewritten paragraph:

Based on the analysis of organic matter carbon isotopes, biomarker compounds, and trace elements, the study identified significant differences in the depositional environment of lacustrine shale in the study area and the sources of organic matter (Fig. 11). During the Sq3 period, the study area represented a dry and saline closed lake basin, and the presence of regular steranes and carbon isotopes collectively indicates that the primary source of organic matter was predominantly terrestrial higher plants. In the Sq2 period, Gammacerane/(Gammacerane+C30Hopane) ratio indicates a marine transgression in the study area, introducing a significant nutrient influx. Additionally, carbon isotopes suggest that plankton predominantly contributed to the organic matter, with localized inputs from higher plants. In the Sq1 period, the presence of C27⁃C28⁃C29 regular steranes, rearranged steranes, and carbon isotopes collectively point to plankton as the primary contributor of organic matter.

Since the Silurian, many basins have experienced marine transgressions as a result of the global rise in sea level. While large-scale marine transgressions were mainly concentrated in the Mesozoic and Cenozoic, evidence of marine transgressions can be found during the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic periods. Marine transgressions are common events in terrestrial lake basins and significantly impact the development of hydrocarbon source rocks. The location of organic matter enrichment in terrestrial lake basins is often closely associated with the stratigraphic positioning of marine transgression. Firstly, marine transgressions introduce a substantial amount of marine plankton into the lake, enhancing paleolake productivity and altering the source type of organic matter to some extent. Secondly, the nutrient elements carried by seawater improve lake water conditions, leading to increased primary productivity of the lake. In addition, alkaline water and seawater have the capacity to hold more CO2 and CO32-, providing carbon sources for the photosynthesis of algae and submerged plants in the water, thus enhancing the primary productivity of lake organic matter. This could explain how under high lake level and sea level conditions resulting in the connection of the Subei Basin with the paleo-ocean, alkaline and saline water invaded the paleo-lake, promoting primary biological productivity and contributing to the accumulation of organic matter. Understanding the mechanism of organic matter (OM) accumulation under the influence of intermittent seawater intrusion and analyzing the intrinsic connection between marine transgression events and the development of hydrocarbon source rocks will provide crucial geological constraints for further study of lacustrine shale deposition and associated geological events.

Rewritten paragraph:

Since the Silurian period, numerous basins have undergone marine transgressions due to the global sea level rise. Although large-scale marine transgressions were primarily concentrated in the Mesozoic and Cenozoic eras, evidence of marine transgressions can be found throughout the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic periods. Marine transgressions are frequent occurrences in terrestrial lake basins and have a profound impact on the formation of hydrocarbon source rocks. The positioning of organic matter enrichment in terrestrial lake basins is often closely linked to the stratigraphic distribution of marine transgressions. Firstly, marine transgressions introduce a significant quantity of marine plankton into the lake, enhancing paleolake productivity and causing partial alterations in the source composition of organic matter. Secondly, the nutrient elements transported by seawater improve the lake's water conditions, resulting in enhanced primary productivity. Moreover, alkaline water and seawater possess the capacity to retain higher levels of CO2 and CO32-, thereby supplying carbon sources for the photosynthesis of algae and submerged plants in the water, consequently enhancing the primary productivity of organic matter in the lake. This mechanism could elucidate how, under high lake and sea level conditions that led to the connection between the Subei Basin and the paleo-ocean, alkaline and saline water intruded into the ancient lake, fostering primary biological productivity and facilitating the accumulation of organic matter. Gaining an understanding of the mechanism behind the accumulation of organic matter (OM) under the influence of intermittent seawater intrusion and analyzing the inherent correlation between marine transgression events and the formation of hydrocarbon source rocks will offer critical geological constraints for future investigations on the deposition of lacustrine shale and associated geological phenomena.

Organic matter enrichment in lacustrine shale is primarily dependent on factors including paleo-salinity, paleoclimate, and paleo-redox conditions. Warm and humid climates favor organic matter production, while oxygen-deficiency and limited freshwater input facilitate its preservation. 
In the Sq3, increasing evaporation leads to elevated salinity and reduced primary biological productivity. The deep lake area is predominantly characterized by a reducing environment. However, the influence of terrigenous plants results in the production of a small amount of type II organic matter. During this time, the lake basin becomes closed and salinized, leading to unfavorable conditions for organic matter preservation. Intermittent transgression occurs during the peak section, with the deep lake area still maintaining a reducing environment. As the influence of seawater intrusion weakens, the Sq1 evolves into a closed lake basin characterized by a warm and humid freshwater environment with high primary productivity. The deep lake area preserves a significant amount of organic matter. The proposed organic matter enrichment model for the study area serves as a theoretical basis for understanding hydrocarbon source rock development and predicting high-quality hydrocarbon source rock layers in other lacustrine basins experiencing transgression. It further advances our understanding of hydrocarbon source rock mechanisms in transgression lacustrine basins and guides oil and gas exploration.

We have discussed the defect mode optical properties of a photonic crystal with a defect layer made of gsst material. GSST is a phase change material whose optical properties depend on its phase state (amorphous, crystalline or intermediate states). To investigate the effect of the GSST defect layer on the optical spectra of the structure, the transmission, reflection and absorption spectra of the structure under oblique radiation were investigated. showed that in the presence of the defect layer, a transmission peak, a reflection well, and an absorption peak depending on the polarization and the GSST state are formed in the region inside the photonic band gap in two fully amorphous and fully crystalline states of GSST. The intensity and position of this defect mode can be adjusted by changing the phase rate of GSST, the thickness of the defect layer, the radiation angle, and the frequency of the photonic crystal. Also, Goss-Hanchen displacement of transmitted and reflected waves with TM polarization near the defect mode wavelength was investigated. The results showed that in the fully amorphous state, the reflected beam exhibits a large negative Gauss-Hanchen shift near the defect mode. In this case, the transmitted beam shows a positive Gauss-Hanchen displacement near the defect mode. In addition, we observed that the amount of negative displacement of the reflection beam is much more significant than the positive displacement of the transmission beam. Also, by examining Goss-Hanchen displacement when the GSST defect layer is in crystalline state, we observed that the amount of positive displacement of the passing beam is reduced and its position is also shifted towards larger wavelengths. Also in this case we did not observe any shift near the wavelength of the defect mode for the reflected beam. We also showed that by changing the phase rate, the amount and position of the Gauss-Hanchen displacement of the reflection and transmission beam changes.

We have investigated the optical properties of a photonic crystal with a defect layer composed of GSST material. GSST is a phase change material, and its optical characteristics vary depending on its phase state, which can be amorphous, crystalline, or in an intermediate state. Our study aimed to explore the impact of the GSST defect layer on the optical spectra of the structure. We focused on analyzing the transmission, reflection, and absorption spectra of the structure under oblique radiation.

Our findings demonstrated that the presence of the defect layer resulted in the formation of a transmission peak, a reflection well, and an absorption peak within the photonic band gap region. These features were dependent on both the polarization and the phase state of GSST, specifically in the fully amorphous and fully crystalline states. Notably, the intensity and position of this defect mode could be controlled through various factors, including the phase rate of GSST, the thickness of the defect layer, the radiation angle, and the frequency of the photonic crystal.

To further investigate the optical behavior near the defect mode wavelength, we examined the Goss-Hanchen displacement of transmitted and reflected waves, focusing on TM polarization. Our results revealed a substantial negative Gauss-Hanchen shift in the reflected beam near the defect mode in the fully amorphous state. Conversely, the transmitted beam exhibited a positive Gauss-Hanchen displacement in the same vicinity. It is important to note that the negative displacement of the reflection beam was significantly greater than the positive displacement of the transmission beam.

Furthermore, when the GSST defect layer was in a crystalline state, we observed a reduction in the positive displacement of the transmitted beam, accompanied by a shift towards longer wavelengths. Interestingly, no apparent shift was observed near the wavelength of the defect mode for the reflected beam in this case. Our study also established that the amount and position of the Gauss-Hanchen displacement of both reflection and transmission beams can be modulated by varying the phase rate.

In conclusion, our research sheds light on the defect mode optical properties of a photonic crystal with a GSST defect layer. By investigating the transmission, reflection, absorption spectra, as well as the Goss-Hanchen displacement, we have provided valuable insights into the behavior of this structure under oblique radiation.

We have discussed the optical properties of defect modes in a photonic crystal that incorporates a GSST material defect layer. GSST is a phase-change material known for its optical properties, which vary depending on its phase state, whether it is amorphous, crystalline, or in an intermediate state. In order to investigate the impact of the GSST defect layer on the optical spectra of the structure, we examined the transmission, reflection, and absorption spectra under oblique radiation.

Our findings revealed that the presence of the defect layer leads to the formation of transmission peaks, reflection wells, and absorption peaks within the photonic band gap region. The occurrence and characteristics of these features are dependent on the polarization and phase state of the GSST material, particularly in the fully amorphous and fully crystalline states. Notably, the intensity and position of these defect modes can be adjusted by manipulating the phase rate of GSST, the thickness of the defect layer, the radiation angle, and the frequency of the photonic crystal.

Additionally, we conducted an investigation into the Goss-Hanchen displacement of transmitted and reflected waves under TM polarization near the defect mode wavelength. Our results demonstrated a significant negative Gauss-Hanchen shift in the reflected beam in the fully amorphous state near the defect mode. Conversely, the transmitted beam exhibited a positive Gauss-Hanchen displacement in the same region. It is important to note that the magnitude of the negative displacement in the reflection beam outweighed the positive displacement in the transmission beam.

Furthermore, when the GSST defect layer was in a crystalline state, we observed a reduction in the positive displacement of the transmitted beam, accompanied by a shift towards longer wavelengths. Interestingly, no apparent shift was observed near the wavelength of the defect mode for the reflected beam in this case. We also established that changes in the phase rate can alter both the magnitude and position of the Gauss-Hanchen displacement in the reflection and transmission beams.

In conclusion, our research delves into the defect mode optical properties of a photonic crystal with a GSST defect layer. By investigating the transmission, reflection, absorption spectra, as well as the Goss-Hanchen displacement, we have gained valuable insights into the behavior of this structure under oblique radiation.

She couldn't focus on mundane tasks like cleaning or laundry. Her mind was consumed with thoughts of the upcoming event. The anticipation made it impossible for her to concentrate on anything else.

She imagined herself in an elegant gown, dancing the night away with her husband by her side. The image of them laughing, surrounded by a crowd of friends, brought a smile to her face.

The hours seemed to drag on as she anxiously awaited the evening. Every passing minute felt like an eternity. She couldn't wait to get dressed up and escape into a world of whimsy and enchantment.

As the clock struck six, she hurriedly began getting ready. She meticulously chose the perfect costume, ensuring that her outfit would be the talk of the party. The excitement surged through her veins, giving her newfound energy.

With each passing moment, her excitement grew exponentially. She imagined all the fun they would have at the party, the memories they would create together. The mundane household chores could wait for another day; tonight was all about letting loose and embracing the festivities.

As she left her house and stepped into the car with her husband, she couldn't stop smiling. The night ahead held promises of merriment and delight. The fancy-dress evening party was the perfect escape from the mundane reality of everyday life.

No longer burdened by mundane responsibilities, she fully immersed herself in the festivities. Dancing, laughter, and bliss filled the air, and for that one magical night, she allowed herself to let go and embrace the joyous spirit of the event.

The evening was a success, filled with laughter, music, and an abundance of cherished memories. As they returned home, tired but content, she couldn't help but feel grateful for the escape the fancy-dress evening party had provided.

The next day, as she woke up to a messy house, she felt a renewed sense of motivation. The memories of the previous night lingered, but she knew it was time to return to her responsibilities.

With a smile on her face and a heart full of cherished memories, she started tackling the housework with a newfound energy. The party had given her the necessary break from reality, rejuvenating her spirit and reminding her of the importance of embracing life's moments of celebration.

From that day forward, she approached her chores with a lighter heart, always keeping in mind the joyous night she had experienced and the dance of life she intended to keep alive.

The number of students who indulge themselves into mobile phones are proliferating in this well developed world. This report aims at rectifying the problem and delving into finding measures to alleviate the disconcerting phenomenon.

The number of students who indulge themselves in mobile phones is proliferating in this well-developed world. This report aims to rectify the problem and delve into finding measures to alleviate this disconcerting phenomenon.

Changes made:
- "are proliferating" changed to "is proliferating" to agree with the singular subject "number"
- "into" added before "finding measures"
- "the" added before "disconcerting phenomenon"
Is this mistake? delve into finding measures

Yes, "delve into finding measures" is not grammatically incorrect, but it can be improved for clarity and conciseness. Here is an alternative suggestion:

This report aims to rectify the problem and delve into measures to alleviate this disconcerting phenomenon.

In this revised version, the phrase "finding measures" is simplified to "measures" for a more straightforward and concise expression.
Can I change proliferating to burgeoning

Yes, you can change "proliferating" to "burgeoning" in your sentence. Here is the revised sentence:

The number of students who indulge themselves in mobile phones is burgeoning in this well-developed world. This report aims to rectify the problem and delve into measures to alleviate this disconcerting phenomenon.

"Burgeoning" is a synonym for "proliferating" and conveys the idea of rapid growth or increase, which works well in the context of the sentence.

The first contributing factor of this  mounting problem is the indulgence of video games.  Gone are the days when teenagers fended for themselves by working with part time jobs. Instead, adolescents are accustomed to stay at home by the reason of their indolence.

The first contributing factor to this mounting problem is the indulgence in video games. Gone are the days when teenagers fended for themselves by working part-time jobs. Instead, adolescents are accustomed to staying at home due to their indolence.

Changes made:
- "of" changed to "to" in the phrase "The first contributing factor of this mounting problem"
- "the reason of" changed to "due to" for better clarity and conciseness
- "by the reason of their indolence" changed to "due to their indolence" for better sentence structure and flow

Some parents satisfy their children’s desire in a wrong way. They indulge teenagers’ lavishness which give rise to their indolence. Accordingly, they become Neets who are reluctant to integrate into society and pessimistic about their career

Some parents satisfy their children's desires in the wrong way, indulging their teenagers' lavishness, which in turn gives rise to their indolence. Consequently, these teenagers become NEETs who are reluctant to integrate into society and pessimistic about their careers.

Changes made:
- "teenagers'" changed to "teenagers'" for possessive form
- "accordingly" changed to "consequently" for better flow and linking of ideas
- "become Neets" changed to "become NEETs" for capitalization consistency (NEET stands for "Not in Education, Employment, or Training")
- "who are reluctant to" added before "integrate into society" for grammatical clarity
- "pessimistic about their career" changed to "pessimistic about their careers" for plural consistency (teenagers have multiple career prospects)
Why not using accordingly

Using "accordingly" would not be incorrect in this context. However, "consequently" has been suggested as an alternative to provide variety and avoid repetition of the same transitional word. Both words convey a cause-and-effect relationship effectively. If you prefer to use "accordingly" instead, you can certainly do so:

Some parents satisfy their children's desires in the wrong way, indulging their teenagers' lavishness, which in turn gives rise to their indolence. Accordingly, these teenagers become NEETs who are reluctant to integrate into society and pessimistic about their careers.
What is the meaning of in turn

The phrase "in turn" is used to describe a sequence or chain of events where one thing leads to or influences another thing, subsequently causing a result or outcome. It indicates a cause-and-effect relationship between different elements or actions. In other words, one action or event happens as a result of the previous action or event.

In the given context, "in turn" is used to explain that indulging teenagers' lavishness leads to their indolence.

The flourishing of the Kong has stirred up a host of thorny problems.

- "aroused" changed to "stirred up" for a more common and idiomatic expression.
- "a host of" added before "thorny problems" for emphasis and clarity.
The flourishing of the cut-throat competitions in Hong Kong has aroused a host of thorny problems.

The flourishing of cut-throat competitions in Hong Kong has sparked a myriad of thorny problems.

Changes made:
- "the cut-throat competitions" added for specificity and clarity.
- "aroused" changed to "sparked" for a more vibrant and dynamic expression.
- "a host of" changed to "a myriad of" for a more evocative and varied description.

Article was the peculiar function word of English. The English article system include the indefinite article a/an, definite article the and zero article. Article have the highest using frequency in English language, the, a and an occupy the 8.5% of whole discourses. English article is hard to master and use for Chinese students who have no article in mother language. Foreign study of article acquisition have started early and have quite rich outcome; but this kind of empirical research are rare in China. Domestic and foreign study of Chinese English learner using articles will mention the three points: 1) no matter what level’s learner, the misusing of article is widely exist; 2) the misusing of can divided to three types: article omit, redundancy and confusion. 3) Among the three types of misuse, article omit have the highest error rate, and in the article confusion, the confusion of a/the was the most frequency one.

Here is a corrected version:

"Article is a peculiar function word in English. The English article system includes the indefinite articles a/an, the definite article the, and the zero article. Articles have the highest frequency of use in the English language, with 'the', 'a', and 'an' occupying 8.5% of all discourse. Mastering and using English articles can be difficult for Chinese students who do not have articles in their mother language. Despite early and rich research on foreign study of article acquisition, there has been limited empirical research on this topic in China. Both domestic and foreign studies of Chinese English learners using articles point to three key points. First, the misuse of articles is widespread among learners at all levels. Second, the misuse of articles can be divided into three categories: omission, redundancy, and confusion. Third, article omission is the most frequent error, and confusion between 'a' and 'the' is the most common form of article confusion."

whenever I do a big important readout.... I generally start with an Executive Summary Page that has a high-level summary of the key points and some detail on each. the problem is: when I start here.... it's a lot of text and you desire to get to the supporting analysis where you see interesting charts and graphs and insights. any presentation advice on how to navigate balancing the Exec Summary with the Supporting Analysis that is rich in detail?

One approach to balance the Executive Summary with the Supporting Analysis is to use a structure that gradually takes your audience from high-level to more detailed points. Start with a brief introduction that sets the context and highlights the key themes of the presentation. Then, move to the Executive Summary Slide, which should provide a concise overview of the key points, but avoid too much detail. 

After that, you can move to the Supporting Analysis slides that include charts, graphs, and other detailed insights. Group these slides by theme or topic, and use headings and subheadings to guide your audience through them. As you go through the Supporting Analysis section, remember to highlight the most relevant and salient points that support your Executive Summary.

Finally, end the presentation with your key takeaways, recommendations, or call-to-actions that follow logically from the Supporting Analysis. This ensures your audience leaves with a clear understanding of the information presented, while leaving enough to support any subsequent questions or discussions.

An important debate has emerged regarding the climate of the Jurassic period, particularly during the middle-late Jurassic transitional period. Some authors (Norris and Hallam, 1995; Jacquin et al., 1998; Hallam, 2001; Wierzbowski et al., 2009) consider this period as a global warming event, characterized by a significant sea-level rise (Wierzbowski et al., 2009; Wierzbowski and Rogov, 2011). These changes were driven by enhanced volcanic activity, tectonic uplift of oceanic ridges, and the reorganization of the seafloor oceanic spreading, which increased greenhouse gases and atmospheric CO2 concentration (Wierzbowski et al., 2009, 2012), and are believed to have caused the climate warming (Sellwood and Valdes, 2008; Holz et al., 2015). However, other studies (Dromart et al., 2003; Nunn, 2009; Price and Rogov, 2009; and Donnadieu et al., 2011) have suggested the opposite hypothesis. They propose that the middle-late Jurassic transitional period (160 Ma) may correspond to a severe "cooling event," with an abrupt global-scale fall of sea level suggestive of continental ice formation. Such changes are attributed to global cooling (Scotese et al., 2021).

Accurately depicting the extent of paleoclimate change in the western edge of the northern Gondwana passive margin and related Intrarif-Mesorif-Prerif sub-domains, which possess several attributes of a “paleo-Critical Zone” as defined by Nordt et al. The primary objective of this study is multi-faceted and aimed at providing new insights and clear constraints on the paleoclimate and related Earth processes. Additionally, we aim to evaluate and understand chemical weathering mechanisms and the efficient transfer of fluxes from source to sink under altered climatic conditions, assess the paleo-redox conditions and related depositional palaeoenvironments and paleoproductivity, enhance our comprehension of the floral landscape and related paleogeography based on the geochemistry record of the sedimentary rocks, and contextualize the obtained data within regional and global frameworks. This comprehensive study aims to contribute to a more thorough and nuanced understanding of paleoclimate change in this critical region, and provide valuable insights to the broader scientific community.

The variation of Earth’s surface landscape throughout geological time results from the interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic forces, and both are controlled by first-order tectonic plate geodynamics under varying climatic conditions. Understanding this interplay is crucial for determining the evolution of Earth’s surface processes and predicting future climate change scenarios. The balance between intrinsic and extrinsic forces triggers the uplift of orogens and connected subsiding basins, and the denudation of the built orogen’s relief. It is therefore important to track the Earth’s past climate change and understand its interaction with Earth’s subsystems, including the geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere, from source to sink. This knowledge will help to better understand the evolution of Earth’s surface processes and their complex interactions with Earth’s subsystems through geological time and to predict future climate change scenarios (see Tierney et al., 2020).
The scientific community is now showing worldwide interest in climate change and its impact on the geological record as it can better constrain our knowledge on the topic. Although the early alpine history during the Jurassic of prominent landform plate assemblages is well known, little data regarding their climate and related climate-process systems are available. Therefore, further research is necessary to enhance our knowledge of the Jurassic climate, mainly in areas belonging to the northern Gondwana boundary (see Price and Sellwood, 1997; Price and Page, 2008; Riccardi, 1991; Podlaha et al., 1998; Price and Gröcke, 2002; Gröcke et al., 2003; Fürsich et al., 2005; Lécuyer and Bucher, 2006; Jenkyns et al., 2012; Alberti et al., 2012a, b, 2013, 2017; 2019).
Some authors (e.g., Hallam, 1993; Sellwood and Valdes, 2006, 2008; Holz, 2015; Li et al., 2022) consider the Jurassic climate to have been warm, while others (e.g. Dromart et al., 2003; Royer 2006; Bodin et al., 2017, 2020; Krencker et al., 2019; and Scotese et al., 2021) report the occurrence of “cool modes” in the middle Jurassic climate, qualified as “Callovian Ice Age” (e.g. Dromart et al., 2003).
The climate change that occurred during the Jurassic period is of paramount interest as it highlights the climate process systems in the northern boundary of the Gondwana realm. This region was a wide northwestern Gondwana passive margin of the Tethysian realm. Numerous studies have examined climate changes during the Jurassic period. Takashima et al. (2006) discovered that this period was a classical greenhouse era characterized by high atmospheric CO2 concentration. Dera et al. (2011) suggested that the high CO2 concentration provides an appropriate modern-day analogy to better understand climate changes throughout Earth’s history. More recent studies by Tierney et al. (2020), Scotese (2021), Skea et al. (2022), and Burgener et al. (2023) have also aimed to contribute to our understanding of Earth’s climate change over geological time. Such research is crucial for comprehending why and how the climate has changed and for predicting future climate shifts.
The middle Jurassic epoch was a significant geological period marked by major global geological events in Earth’s history (Dera et al., 2011). First-order plate tectonics triggered the final breakup of Pangea and Gondwana, as well as subsequent continental rifting. These events led to the opening of new seaways and the initiation of seafloor spreading in the central Atlantic, the western Tethys, and large-scale oceanic corridors. Bartolini and Larson (2001) and Martini and Ortega-Gutierrez (2018) have provided evidence of this process. Additionally, research by Labails et al. (2010), Dera et al. (2015), and Scotese et al. (2021) has further elucidated the extent and impact of these geological events.
These events occurred concurrently with climate fluctuations that began during the late early Jurassic period. This period was marked by a shift from the late Pliensbachian “cool event” as described by Korte and Hesselbo (2011) and Korte et al. (2015) to the warm Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event (TOAE) as documented by Jenkyns (1988), Bailey et al. (2003), Rosales et al. (2004), and Korte et al. (2015). Since the early Aalenian, the climate has shifted back to a cooling event, as reported by Korte et al. (2015).
An important debate has been raised exclusively for the Jurassic climate during the critical middle-late Jurassic transitional period considered by some authors (Norris and Hallam ,1995; Jacquin et al.,1998; Hallam ,2001; Wierzbowski et al. ,2009) as a global warming event, with a significant sea-level rise (Wierzbowski et al., 2009; Wierzbowski and Rogov, 2011), driven by enhanced volcanic activity, tectonic uplift of oceanic ridges, and the reorganization of the seafloor oceanic spreading which increased greenhouse gases considered as a potential source of the atmospheric CO2 concentration raise during thisperiod (Wierzbowski et al., 2009, 2012), and therefore responsible for the climate warming Sellwood and Valdes, (2008); Holz et al., (2015).On the other hand, Dromart et al. (2003); Nunn (2009); Price and Rogov (2009); and Donnadieu et al. (2011) supported an opposite hypothesis suggesting that the middle-late Jurassic transitional period (160 Ma) may correspond to a severe “cooling event” simultaneous with an abrupt global-scale fall of sea level suggestive of continental ice formation at this time and due to a global cooling (Scotese et al., 2021).
The main knowledge accumulated about the Earth is mainly reported from marine records (e.g., Alberti et al., 2020). Here, we are more interested in the middle Jurassic climate of mid-latitude provinces where seawater temperatures were cool (about 10°C), occurring coevally with the northern Sea Dome in the southern part of the Viking Corridor. This dome was responsible for large-scale volcanic activity, impacting oceanic circulation by preventing the equatorial warm oceanic current from reaching the Northern Polar region (Korte et al., 2015).
To forecast the Earth’s surface processes under Jurassic climate change in the northern African passive margin, a combination of different geochemical proxies (including major, trace, and rare earth elements) and clay mineralogy have been utilized. This approach aims to better assess weathering intensity, chemical variations, and sediment supply from continental sources to neighboring oceanic sinks under Jurassic paleoclimatic conditions. Such conditions can impact sediment and organic matter redistribution in the oceanic sink, particularly by the near-surface hydrological source to sink processes.

conversation.content: What is my problem? Today is June 20, 2023; and, I will try my best to explain my own circumstance(s) since the problem originated: My name is James, and I am a rising Junior (Tenth Grader Entering Eleventh Grade) -- and high school has not been too great for me since the second semester of freshman year (ninth grade). When I entered the ninth grade, I was a very prolific person and wrote powerful, persuasive essays---writing was a testament to my skill and ability; and thus was my math, albeit I did make silly, nonchalant and nonsensical errors from time-to-time. However, my English grades were a strong point and I had had indefitagible strength with it. However, around December 2021, I suddenly began to complain about my writing skill. My ideas were harder to captivate; yet, I could avoid these issues and elude them efficiently. They were tolerable; and my writing was still on-par -- great and fantastical. However, suddenly around early December 2021, I lost my ability to write. I sat down onto a comfortable chair, with everything in position; however, no matter how much force (nor motivation) was spurred, I never had had the talent (again) to manage such excellent writing pieces. I ran out of motivation and began to struggle. Much to my dismay, I felt lazy and lethargic from it. But, what saved me was simple: there was winter break. I thought I had been O.K.; perhaps I was burnt out, but my mind foreshadowed otherwise (after all -- it doesn't make any sense for a ninth grade to suffer from burn out -- especially since, for most, it occurs during their senior year (12th grade)). After winter break, I realized this problem was not just mutually exclusive to english and writing: it was to every criteria. I was not as humorous as before, and I felt more 'dead'. My jokes were not as funny; nor could I think of as much ideas as I could beforehand. No amount of compensate beared witness -- as a testimony- -- to my previous skillset which I possessed; ergo, I began to work last second on every assignment, just before I'd get the assignments late. My teachers' caught me for such and severerly reprimanded me for my laziness around Mid-April 2022. I began feeling melancholy, because no matter how much effort I put into my work, it would never be as much as I would hope or need. I would struggle---and my laziness seemingly grew. My parents, much to my dismay, did not know what to do and reprimanded me -- because they thought it was psychological; I don't know if it is -- but, I do know one thing: they said that, even if it was, there was nothing they could do -- and therefore, complaining was useless. So, I succumbed to agony and misery throughout Summer Break with a minor form of incessant melancholy -- albeit, I dreamt of my returnal to my writing skill. Oh, how much I succeeded at the first semester of ninth grade! I dare say, to this day, it was the most improvement I have ever, ever had in my skill! But all of it -- somehow, was thrown into waste; and I yearn for such to return to this day. Summer break loomed, as said beforehand for the months of June to Early August 2020. I did not indulge in any writing in this period -- under the pretense that distracting myself from writing would help cure the condition; after all, I was very, very desperate. My parents did not care -- and were tired of my inexhaustible gloom and miseries of a near-formidable grade collapse in the second semester. But a very taint motivation begun appearing for the first semester of tenth grade around August 2022, when the school year begun. I begun taking full honors courses, and I had difficulties as before. They were a bit more manageable, but there was no tangible difference in my writing performance; and, as I dare say, it was the same as before when the issues started--and this would persist as I begun to cheat on assignments to save my grade. But, I found solace in a simple thing: while I struggled with anything involving writing, I suddenly begun improving with math; the very thing which I hated since pre-algebraic introduction in the sixth grade (2019) due to math anxiety faded--I was excellent! I began working on that to "soothe my wounds", but the transition was detestable and, in my opinion, wasn't as worthwhile as adeptness in English. One day around Late October to Early November 2022, I was assigned with a literary critique essay, which I knew would happen because of my elder classmates last year, who asked me for help on such before my writers' block. (I obliged at the time in 2021, during my first semester of ninth grade, but I felt jealous of how skillful they were in 2021; and this might have, maybe might have caused my motivation to dwindle and all my creativity, consequently). Days and days before I began writing, I just couldn't; no ideas were in fruition -- nothing; not even cheating could suffice. But, on the last day before it was due, I began "forcing" my creativity out and it worked: it was the best piece of writing I had ever written! It was a success -- the best I had ever seen! A phD level of glory and love; and this was relished by my peers and my teachers; and another assignment arose in November to December 2022: a 'scene' I must write of a story narrative; and such I did, which was great as well, but it was from likely Eustress, lovely and taint in all demeanor -- wrote in one go with minor editing meant to suffice my will. It was looking great, and my writing skill began to cultivate; but this blitz ended immediately after the Winter Break (First Semester) of my tenth grade, from December 2022 to January 2023. It ended; and I was right back to where I started. Fortunately, CHATGPT was invented at this time, so I used that to help in all my writing assignments afterward -- and I didn't care; and I didn't have timed essays at the time, which is great (and still don't; but I will in the eleventh grade). Fortunately, I managed to pass with straight-As' and go on, and now, it is summer break. I don't have any ideas, and I think I am in a worse-off spot than I was before. I yearn for my creative attributes -- and especially of the excellences int he brief lapses of non-creativity into creativity! Honestly, I refuse to believe i wrote the excellent essay and story, and I wish I could retrieve them. You know--with all the blood and soul poured into all the works; I wish I could retrieve them back; and I aspire! And that's what I inquire from you: why is this happening; and how could i fix it? I want my former glory, especially that of the quality where I wrote my story scene narrative and my essay. The best I had ever done! I want it consistent! I want to know how! It's not just forcing it which works; I only feel tainted and melancholic -- with nothing happening, but just stagnation; but those, were rare moments, lapses of not having creativity into endless bubbles of creativity filled with perfectionism. I ask you!

Based on the information provided, it appears that your main problem is experiencing writer's block and a general lack of creativity and motivation. This has affected your academic performance and caused you to struggle with assignments, resulting in cheating and reprimands from your teachers. Additionally, you experience feelings of melancholy and frustration, and you yearn to retrieve your former writing abilities and consistency.

There could be several factors contributing to your writer's block and lack of motivation, including burnout, anxiety, negative self-talk, stress from academic pressures, and other psychological factors. It may be helpful to speak with a counselor or therapist to explore these possibilities further and develop coping strategies.

Additionally, engaging in activities that promote creativity and reduce stress, such as meditation, exercise, and leisure time, may help to stimulate your creativity and motivation. You could also try setting achievable writing goals, practicing writing exercises, and seeking feedback from peers and teachers to help improve your writing skills.

Ultimately, it may take time and patience to overcome your writer's block and regain your former glory, but with persistence and support, it is possible to overcome this challenge.
Please, explain to me what might be the cause and a way to fix t

Based on the information you provided, there could be several factors contributing to your difficulty with writing and your overall lack of creativity and motivation. It may be helpful to explore some of the following potential causes:

1. Burnout: It is possible that your intense focus on writing during your ninth grade year led to burnout, where you became exhausted and unable to continue at the same level of focus and intensity. To fix this, you may need to take more breaks, engage in activities you enjoy that are not related to writing, and give yourself permission to rest and recharge.

2. Anxiety: Writing and other forms of creative expression can be challenging for many people, especially if they experience anxiety around performance or self-evaluation. If you feel anxious when you sit down to write, it may be helpful to practice relaxation techniques or seek professional counseling to help reduce your anxiety.

3. Negative self-talk: If you are constantly criticizing yourself and telling yourself that you are not a good writer, this can create a self-fulfilling prophecy. To fix this, try to challenge negative thoughts and replace them with positive ones. Consider keeping a journal and writing down positive affirmations about your writing.

4. Perfectionism: Perfectionism can be a significant roadblock to creativity and motivation, as it can create an unrealistic standard that is difficult to meet. To fix this, try to remind yourself that being human means making mistakes and that the journey is more important than the destination. Focus on progress rather than perfection.

5. Academic Pressure: The pressure to succeed academically can be overwhelming, and this pressure may be contributing to your writer's block. It may be helpful to talk with your teachers or a guidance counselor to explore ways to reduce stress and pressure.

To fix your current situation, you may need to take a step back from writing and give yourself a break. Spend time doing activities that you enjoy, and don't put pressure on yourself to write. When you do sit down to write, try to set achievable goals, and don't be too hard on yourself if you don't produce something perfect. Finally, be patient with yourself. Overcoming writer's block and regaining your creativity may take time, but with effort and support, it is possible.

It sounds like you have been relying on external sources for help with your writing, such as CHATGPT or peers. While it is helpful to seek feedback and support, it is essential to develop your own writing skills independently.

To build your writing skills, consider starting small. Begin with short writing exercises or prompts that focus on different aspects of writing, such as character development, plot, or setting. Use writing books or tutorials to learn about the different elements of writing and practice incorporating them into your writing. Once you feel comfortable with short exercises, move on to longer assignments.

Remember that writing is a process, and it is normal to struggle at times. If you are having trouble, take a break and come back to it later. Try to find inspiration in the world around you, such as music, art, or nature. Finally, seek feedback and support from trusted sources, such as a teacher or mentor, to help you improve your writing skills over time.

Finding ideas for writing can be challenging, especially when you're experiencing writer's block. However, there are several strategies you might try to help overcome this challenge:

1. Freewriting: Set a timer for 10-15 minutes and write continuously without stopping or editing yourself. This allows you to break through mental blocks and generate new ideas.

2. Brainstorming: Jot down any idea that comes to mind, no matter how silly or far-fetched it may seem. Once you have a list of ideas, you can work on developing them into a coherent piece of writing.

3. Change your surroundings: Sometimes a change of scenery can help spark creativity. Try writing in a different location or going for a walk to generate new ideas.

4. Read: Reading books, articles, and other forms of writing can help generate new ideas and spark inspiration.

5. Multiple drafts: Don't be afraid to write multiple drafts of a piece. It's okay if your initial attempt is not perfect. Sometimes just putting words on paper can help you break through your mental block and start generating new ideas.

Remember to be patient with yourself through this process. Overcoming writer's block takes time and effort, but with dedication and persistence, you can overcome this challenge and start generating new ideas again.

Sure, here is the edited version of your writing:

Despite the wide array of teaching methodologies available to educators, some teachers still rely on traditional methods when teaching. While factors such as economic barriers, educational backgrounds, and material resources can play a role in this occurrence, the inner factors - such as the teacher's beliefs - can also influence their teaching strategies. Every teacher has their own beliefs about learning, teaching, subjects, and education as a whole, and these beliefs can ultimately shape their teaching methodologies.

Firstly, a teacher's belief about learning can lead to different teaching methods. For instance, if a teacher subscribes to the behavior theory of learning, they might prefer to use traditional teaching methodologies that rely on endless repetition and practice. Secondly, a teacher's own views about their subject can also influence the specific teaching methodologies they use. A teacher who views language as nothing more than a linguistic system may be less inclined to use methodologies such as communicative language teaching or task-based language teaching. 

Thirdly, a teacher's preference for student-centered or teacher-centered methods might be influenced by how they view the student and their relationship during the learning process. Finally, a teacher's view of knowledge can determine their openness to new teaching methods. Teachers who view knowledge as a dynamic concept rather than a static truth may be more open to trying out new teaching methodologies that fit different learning situations.

In conclusion, teachers consider various factors when selecting teaching methodologies according to their personal beliefs. Teachers should continuously learn and be willing to try new methodologies to enable the development of their students.
Feedback please

As an AI language model, I am designed to assist you with various language tasks such as proofreading, suggesting grammar corrections, and suggestions for improving clarity and logical flow. 

If you would like to receive feedback on a specific piece of writing, then please feel free to send me your writing prompt, and I will be glad to assist you.

Highlight the grammar mistake I made, correct it, and tell me the reason why please.
Even there are so many different teaching methodologies that teachers could use in their teaching, some teachers still rely their traditional teaching methodology. Except the reason of economy, educational background and other material factors, do other inner factors like teacher’s beliefs influence his / her teaching methodology. All teachers have their own beliefs on learning, teaching, subjects, education and other factors influence their teaching. In my opinion, all of this beliefs have potentially influence teacher’s teaching methodology.
Firstly, different belief of learning leads to different teaching methodology. If a teacher holds the behavior theory on learning, he may like use the traditional teaching methodology that include endless repeat practices. Secondly, that teacher’s belief on their own subject also influence their teaching methodology. Teacher who believe the language is simply a linguistic system is not likely to use the methodology like communicative language teaching or task-based language teaching. Thirdly, the preference of student-centred methodology or teacher-centred methodology may due to how the teacher view the student and the relationship with student during the learning activity. Finally, teacher’s view on knowledge may his / her openness to the new teaching methodologies. See knowledge as dynamic rather than static truth will encourage teachers to change their teaching methodology to adapt to the different situation.
In short, teachers take different factors into consideration when they choose teaching methodologies according to their own belies. Teachers should keep learning and willing to trying mind to new methodology to achieve the better development of students.

Sure, here are the corrected sentences along with explanations:

1. "Even though there are so many different teaching methodologies that teachers could use in their teaching, some teachers still rely on their traditional teaching methodologies." 

Reason for correction: "Even though" is the proper phrase to use to express the contrast between the availability of different teaching methodologies versus the continued use of traditional teaching methods. Also, the noun "methodologies" should be matched with the possessive pronoun "their" to make the sentence clearer.

2. "Except for the reasons of economy, educational background, and other material factors, do other inner factors like a teacher's beliefs influence his/her teaching methodology?"

Reason for correction: It is more natural to use "for" instead of "of" after "except." Additionally, the singular possessive pronoun "his/her" should be changed to "their" to be gender-neutral.

3. "All teachers have their own beliefs on learning, teaching, subjects, and education, and other factors influence their teaching. In my opinion, all of these beliefs have a potentially significant influence on a teacher's teaching methodology." 

Reason for correction: The phrase "all of this beliefs" should be corrected to "all of these beliefs" to match the plural noun "beliefs". In the second sentence, it is clearer to add the phrase "a potentially" before "significant influence."

4. "Firstly, a different belief of learning leads to a different teaching methodology. If a teacher holds the behavior theory of learning, they may like using traditional teaching methodologies that include endless repeat practices."

Reason for correction: "Different belief" should be corrected to "A different belief." "May like using" should be corrected to "may like to use." Also, "endless repeated practices" should be written in the plural form "endless repeat practices" since the use of "practices" implies plural.

5. "Secondly, that teacher’s belief about their own subject also influences their teaching methodology. A teacher who believes that language is simply a linguistic system is not likely to use methodologies like communicative language teaching or task-based language teaching."

Reason for correction:  Use "influences" instead of "influence" to match the singular subject-verb agreement. Use "a teacher" instead of "that teacher" to introduce a new subject. Also, the parallel structure requires "communicative language teaching" and "task-based language teaching" to be written in the plural form to match each other.

6. "Thirdly, the preference of student-centered methodology or teacher-centered methodology may be due to how the teacher views the student and the relationship with the student during the learning activity."

Reason for correction: Add the verb "be" after "may" to create an auxiliary phrase. Replace "due to" with "be due to" to clarify the connection between the two elements of the sentence.

7. "Finally, a teacher’s view on knowledge may influence their openness to new teaching methodologies. Seeing knowledge as a dynamic rather than static truth will encourage teachers to change their teaching methodology to adapt to different situations."

Reason for correction: Use "finally" to indicate that this is the last point you want to make. "Teachers" should be changed to "teacher's" to reflect possessive ownership. Also, use "seeing" instead of "see" to imply the present continuous tense. Use "the different situation" instead of "to different situation" to create proper noun phrases. Lastly, use "teaching methodology" instead of "teaching methodologies" to maintain consistency with previous statements.

I hope this helps!
Thank you!
You're welcome! Don't hesitate to let me know if you need any further assistance.

explain why

The correction was necessary because the original sentence contained grammatical errors that made it unclear and incorrect. Here's the breakdown of the issues and the reasoning behind the corrected version:

1. **Subject-Verb Agreement**: The original fragment "Compound sentences are sentence" mixes singular and plural inappropriately. The subject "Compound sentences" is plural, so the verb should agree by also being plural ("are"), but the noun "sentence" should also match in plurality, becoming "sentences."

2. **Clarification and Completeness**: The phrase "are sentence contains" is grammatically incorrect because it awkwardly merges two ideas without proper structure. In English, a subject followed by a verb should lead to a complete thought (predicate), but here it's jumbled. The corrected version, "are sentences that contain," uses a relative clause ("that contain") to clarify what compound sentences are. This structure is essential for explaining the characteristic of compound sentences properly.

3. **Plural Consistency**: The correction to "two or more clauses" remains as it was correctly used in the original. The term "clauses" correctly implies the compound nature of the sentence, indicating that there are multiple independent or dependent clauses joined by conjunctions, semicolons, or commas (when appropriate).

In summary, the correction provides a clear, grammatically correct sentence that accurately defines compound sentences. The subject and verb agree in number, a relative clause properly introduces the definition, and the plural form is consistently used to reflect the concept of multiplicity inherent to compound sentences.

Both passages effectively convey a message about the unforeseen complexities and consequences of lying, with subtle differences in tone and wording. Here's a breakdown to help you determine which one might be best depending on the context:

1. **Prose Style**: The first passage has a more narrative feel with its choice of words like "deceptive," "stalk," and "the moment the confusion started," which may engage readers on a more dramatic level.
   - **Impactful Vocabulary**: "The simplicity of telling a lie is deceptive" and "false story...came back to stalk me" evoke strong imagery and convey a sense of inevitable doom catching up with the speaker.
   - **Essence of Realization**: The phrase "Yet, might it have been more than just a misunderstanding?" suggests a deeper level of realization or epiphany, prompting the reader to consider underlying truths.

2. **Directness and Clarity**: The second passage is straightforward and clear, using direct language that makes the message immediately accessible to the reader.
   - **Relatability**: "Lying seems simple… until the day you’re confronted with it" is a statement many can relate to, with its simplicity and universal truth about lying.
   - **Continuity and Rhetoric**: It ends on a rhetorical note—"But, could it be that it wasn’t a misunderstanding after all?"—which effectively leaves the reader in suspense, pondering the true nature of the situation.

**Overall Effectiveness**: If your aim is to engage readers with a vivid and reflective narrative, option 1 might be more impactful. It uses language that paints a picture and leaves space for introspection. However, if straightforward relatability and rhetorical punch are what you're after, option 2's clear and unsparing approach might suit your needs better.

Both options have their merits, and the "best" one would depend on the context in which it is used such as the audience, the medium of communication, and the desired emotional or intellectual response.

H/ACA RNP proteins from P. furiosus were purified as previously described (Li and Ye, 2006). The full-length genes of S. islandicus Cbf5, Nop10, Gar1 and L7Ae were PCR-amplified from the S. islandicus REY15A genomic DNA. The Cbf5 gene contains an intron, and its two exons were separately amplified and then joined by overlap PCR. Cbf5-His6 and Nop10 were cloned into MCS1 and MSC2 of the pETDuet-1 plasmid, respectively, and co-expressed. L7Ae, which has a His6 tag at its C-terminus, was cloned into the multiple cloning site 1 (MSC1) of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. Similarly, Gar1 was also cloned into the MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. All plasmids were then transformed into Escherichia coli Rosetta (DE3) strains. 
Cells that co-expressed Cbf5-His6/Nop10 were harvested, and resuspended in buffer A containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6) and 5% glycerol. They were lysed by sonication and heated at 65°C for 15 minutes and clarified by centrifugation. The resulting supernatant was subjected to purification using a HisTrap column that was washed with buffer A containing 20 mM imidazole and ultimately eluted using buffer A with 500 mM imidazole. After a 2-fold dilution, the proteins underwent additional purification via a Heparin column equilibrated in a buffer that contained 0.25 M NaCl and 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6). The proteins were then finally eluted with a 0.5-1 M salt gradient at ~0.8 M NaCl.
Gar1 was lysed in buffer A and heated, as described above. After a 2-fold dilution, Gar1 was subjected to purification through a Heparin column and was eluted using a ~0.5 M NaCl salt gradient. 
Cell that expressed L7Ae-His6 were lysed in buffer C containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.0) and 5% glycerol. Following heat treatment and clarification, L7Ae underwent purification using a HisTrap column which was first washed with buffer C that contained 20 mM imidazole. L7Ae was then eluted with buffer M, which contained 500 mM imidazole and 20 mM MES (pH 6.0). L7Ae was subsequently loaded onto two serial HiTrap Blue HP columns in 20 mM MES (pH 6.0) and ultimately eluted in a salt gradient at around 0.5 M NaCl.

The full-length genes of S. islandicus Cbf5, Nop10, Gar1, and L7Ae were amplified by PCR from S. islandicus REY15A genomic DNA. To join the two exons of Cbf5, overlap PCR was utilized. Cbf5-His6 and Nop10 were cloned into MCS1 and MSC2 of the pETDuet-1 plasmid, respectively, and co-expressed. L7Ae, which has a His6 tag at its C-terminus, was cloned into MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid, while Gar1 was also cloned into MSC1 of the pRSFDuet-1 plasmid. These plasmids were then transformed into Escherichia coli Rosetta (DE3) strains.

To purify cells that co-expressed Cbf5-His6/Nop10, they were harvested, resuspended in buffer A containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6), and 5% glycerol. They underwent sonication, heat treatment, and clarification by centrifugation. After a 2-fold dilution, Heparin column purification was employed in a buffer containing 0.25 M NaCl and 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.6), followed by elution with a 0.5-1 M salt gradient at ~0.8 M NaCl.

Gar1 was lysed in buffer A and heated, and after a 2-fold dilution, Gar1 underwent Heparin column purification and elution using a ~0.5 M NaCl salt gradient.

Cells that expressed L7Ae-His6 were lysed in buffer C containing 1M NaCl, 25 mM phosphate (pH 7.0), and 5% glycerol, then underwent heat treatment and clarification. L7Ae purification involved utilizing a HisTrap column, washing it with buffer C containing 20 mM imidazole, and eluting L7Ae with buffer M containing 500 mM imidazole and 20 mM MES (pH 6.0). Finally, L7Ae was loaded onto two serial HiTrap Blue HP columns in 20 mM MES (pH 6.0) and eluted using a salt gradient at around 0.5 M NaCl.

I know many of you have spent your whole life trying to get to the middle class, and I am about to tell
you it is the wrong goal. Have an open mind. I am going to write an entire book
on this topic one day—but for now, let's just think about breaking out of what I
call the “middle-class mentality.” I believe I can make the case that the middle
class is the group hurt most by its members' thinking and actions—leaving
themselves to be the most susceptible to insecurity and pain. Although this is a
group that many people aspire to be a part of, it's also the group that seems the
most trapped, manipulated, and at risk. Is the middle class really as good a status
as you've been made to believe? Do you even know what it means to be middle
class or what puts a person in this group? Before you make a decision about
where you are going or the group you're striving to belong to, it would be wise to
inspect the statistics of that group. The Incomes of the Middle Class
Reports from Wikipedia and the 2008 Census suggest that the middle-class
income range is somewhere between $35,000 to $50,000 per year. Read another
set of studies, and these figures are between $22,000 and $65,000 per year. It's
no secret that it would be extremely difficult to live on either of these income
levels in an urban area like New York or LA—much less feel financially secure.
This experience is not what most people would consider a desirable situation.
The middle class is further divided into the upper and lower middle class. The
upper middle class usually consists of people who have substantial assets and
household earnings of over $1 million per year, although there is nothing to
substantiate what makes $1 million the mark. I guess it just sounds good. Most
people consider $1 million to be a lot of money—until they have it. Then they
realize that it doesn't go very far since a person's decisions and considerations
tend to change once he or she enters a new income bracket.

### Rethinking the Middle-Class Goal

- **Middle-Class Mentality Critique**
  - Advised to reconsider aspiring for middle-class status as the ultimate goal.
  - Suggests middle-class mentality may lead to insecurity and pain.

- **Trapped and Manipulated**
  - Middle class viewed as most susceptible to being trapped, manipulated, and at risk.
  
- **Income Range Confusion**
  - Varied reports on middle-class income: $35,000 to $50,000 or $22,000 to $65,000 yearly.
  - High cost of living in urban areas challenges financial security at these income levels.

- **Upper vs Lower Middle Class**
  - Upper middle class defined by assets and earnings over $1 million/year.
  - Critique on the perceived value of $1 million, suggesting it may not suffice for financial security.
  
- **Call to Action**
  - Encourages examining the statistics and realities of middle-class status.
  - Highlights the importance of understanding what defines middle-class and questioning its value as a life goal.

### Key Takeaway
- Urges a reevaluation of aiming for middle-class status, highlighting issues of financial security, societal perceptions, and the varying definitions of income levels within this group.
