The people in the supposed upper middle class occupy noticeably higher
positions in their offices and are considered financially more stable than many of
their peers. This may very well be the case—until any sort of economic
destruction occurs. Then we tend to see that even this group is unprotected.
Admittedly, members of this group should experience a considerable rise in their
incomes due to the economic growth of the nation in good times. They have
higher disposable incomes than many of their counterparts in the lower middle
class, which consists of people who have basic educational qualifications and an
annual income of between $30,000 and $60,000. The lower middle class
constitutes a large part of our country's total population. This set frequently
struggles to reach the upper middle class's level; however, when economic
hardship takes hold, everyone gets pulled down.
A client of mine recently asked me via text message on the 26th of a recent
month, “Grant, I have to net $10,000 to keep my doors open this month. How
can I do this?” I happened to get his message during a Sunday football game, so
I asked him, “Are you watching the game today?” He texted me back, “Yes.” I
then replied, “What are you doing taking a Sunday off to watch the game?! You
should be out distributing fliers, spending every second of every hour trying to
create income in excess of what you need. And by the way, you need $100,000
in net profits—not $10,000.” “Sunday,” he responded, “is a day of rest.” Oh boy.
I shot back, “It is for those that worked the other six days! The Lord wasn't
talking to the people who are short on funds and haven't earned the day of rest.
So turn off the game, get off your couch, and go get the money you need! Quit
being a middle-class slave, and go create the income you need to secure wealth
and financial freedom—for yourself and your household and your company!” I
think he got the message.
My client is at risk because he has been operating based on what he needs and
therefore is just “getting by.” Unfortunately, this middle-class mentality will not
create financial security. The banks dried up on him; he could no longer depend
on credit for his cushion, and he can now depend only on his actions. This is the
problem with many members of the middle class. They go after what they've
deemed necessary rather than ever going really big. Most people believe that a
comfortable middle-class life includes clothes, a house, a few cars, vacation
time, maybe an upper-management position, and some money in the bank.
However, depending on the period in history to which we're referring, the term
“middle class” has had a variety of meanings—many of which have been and still are quite contradictory. It has referred to the class of people between
peasants and nobility, whereas other definitions suggest that the middle class had
enough capital to rival nobles. We've clearly come a long way from that meaning
today. For example, in India, the middle class is considered to be those who
reside in an owner-occupied property, whereas a blue-collar job makes you
middle class in the United States—and in Europe, that makes you a member of
the working class.

### Upper Middle Class Vulnerability & Middle-Class Mentality

- **Upper Middle Class Characteristics**
  - Higher office positions, financial stability.
  - Vulnerable in economic downturns despite higher disposable income.

- **Lower Middle Class Struggles**
  - Basic education, annual income $30,000 to $60,000.
  - Majority of the population, aspiring for upper middle class yet often pulled down by economic hardships.

- **Client Case Study: Misguided Financial Priorities**
  - Example of a client needing to net $10,000 to stay afloat.
  - Advised against complacency (e.g., watching Sunday football) when in financial need.
  - Emphasized need for proactive income generation beyond immediate needs.

- **Middle-Class Mentality Critique**
  - Highlights complacency as a risk to financial security.
  - Criticizes reliance on credit and minimalistic financial goals.
  - Advocates for significant ambition over contentment with middle-class comfort.

- **Historical and Geographical Context of Middle Class**
  - Definition has evolved: once between peasants and nobility, now differs by region.
  - In India, associated with homeownership; in the U.S., tied to blue-collar jobs; in Europe, considered working class.

### Key Takeaway
- Both upper and lower middle classes face vulnerabilities, particularly during economic downturns. The critique emphasizes the dangers of the middle-class mentality, advocating for aggressive financial goals and actions to achieve true financial security. The concept of middle class varies greatly by time period and geography, affecting perceptions and financial strategies.

An important aspect of reading is lexical access the identification of a word that allows 
us to retrieve the meaning of the word from memory. Most psychologists who study 
reading believe that lexical access is an interactive process. It combines information of 
different kinds, such as the features of letters, the letters themselves, and the words comprising the letters (Morton, 1969).
Investigators (McClelland, Mirman, & Holt, 2009; Rumelhart & McClelland 1981, 
1982) developed an interactive-activation model suggesting that activation of particular 
lexical elements occurs at multiple levels. Moreover, activity at each of the levels is interactive (Figure 9.5 ). The interactive-activation model distinguishes among three levels of processing 
following visual input—the feature level, the letter level, and the word level. The model 
assumes that information at each level is represented separately in memory. Information 
passes from one level to another bidirectionally. In other words, processing occurs in each 
of two directions. First, it is bottom-up, starting with sensory data and working up to 
higher levels of cognitive processing. Second, it is top-down, starting with high-level cognition operating on prior knowledge and experiences related to a given context. The interactive view implies that we not only use the visually or orally perceptible features of letters 
to help us identify words but also the features we already know about words to help us 
identify letters. For this reason, the model is referred to as “interactive” (Plaut et al., 1996).
Other theorists have suggested alternatives to Rumelhart and McClelland’s model 
(e.g., Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1976; Paap et al., 1982), but the distinctions among interactive models go beyond the scope of this introductory text. Support for word-recognition 
models involving discrete levels of processing comes from studies of cerebral processing 
(Harley, 2008; Petersen et al., 1988; Posner et al., 1988, 1989). Studies that map brain 
metabolism via PET and fMRI (see Chapter 2) indicate that different regions of the brain 
become activated during passive visual processing of word forms, as opposed to semantic analysis of words or even spoken pronunciation of the words. 
In addition to neuropsychological support, a number of word-recognition models have been simulated on computers (e.g., Harm & Seidenberg, 2004). Both models 
aptly predicted a word-superiority effect as well as a pseudo word-superiority effect. The 
word-superiority effect is similar to the configural-superiority effect and the object-superiority effect (mentioned in regard to top-down influences on perception). In the wordsuperiority effect, letters are read more easily when they are embedded in words than 
when they are presented either in isolation or with letters that do not form words. People 
take substantially longer to read unrelated letters than to read letters that form a word 
(Cattell, 1886). This effect is sometimes called the Reicher-Wheeler effect, named for two 
researchers who did early investigations of this effect (Reicher, 1969; Wheeler, 1970).
To observe the word-superiority effect, researchers use an experimental paradigm 
called the lexical-decision task. In this paradigm, a string of letters is presented briefly. 
It then is either removed or covered by a visual mask, a pattern that wipes out the previously presented stimulus from iconic memory (see Chapter 5 for more information 
about the iconic memory store). The participant then is asked to make a decision about 
whether the string of letters is a word.
To observe the word-superiority effect, the standard lexical-decision task is modified 
to examine the processing of letters (see Figure 9.6 ). Participants are more accurate in choosing the correct letter when it is presented in the context of a word than they are in 
choosing the correct letter when it is presented in isolation (Johnston & McClelland, 1973). 
Even letters in pronounceable pseudo words (e.g., “MARD”) are identified more accurately 
than letters in isolation. However, strings of letters that cannot be pronounced as words 
(e.g., “ORWK”) do not aid in identification (Grainger et al., 2003; Pollatsek & Rayner, 1989). 
 Explore Lab 44, Word Superiority, in CogLab.
There is also a sentence-superiority effect (Cattell, 1886; Perfetti, 1985): People take 
about twice as long to read unrelated words as to read words in a sentence (Cattell, 1886). 
The sentence-superiority effect can be seen in other paradigms as well. For example, 
suppose that a reader briefly sees a degraded stimulus. The word window, for example, 
might be shown but in degraded form (Figure 9.7 ). When the word is standing by 
itself in this form, it is more difficult to recognize than when it is preceded by a sentence 
context. An example of such a context would be, “There were several repair jobs to be 
done. The first was to fix the _____.” (Perfetti, 1985). Having a meaningful context for a 
stimulus helps the reader to perceive it.
Context effects work at both conscious and preconscious levels. At the conscious level, 
we have active control over the use of context to determine word meanings. At the preconscious level, the use of context is probably automatic and outside our active control. 
Participants seem to make lexical decisions more quickly when presented with strings of 
letters that commonly are associated pairs of words (e.g., “doctor” and “nurse” or “bread” 
and “butter”). They respond more slowly when presented with unassociated pairs of 
words, with pairs of nonwords, or with pairs involving a word and a nonword (Hyoenae, J., 
& Lindeman, 2008; Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; Schvaneveldt, Meyer, & Becker, 1976).

- Lexical access is important for reading, allowing the retrieval of a word's meaning from memory.
- Interactive process: combines information from letter features, letters, and words (Morton, 1969).
- Interactive-activation model: suggests multiple levels of lexical activation – feature, letter, and word levels. This process is bidirectional, encompassing both bottom-up (sensory data to cognition) and top-down (prior knowledge and context) processing (McClelland et al., 2009; Rumelhart & McClelland, 1981, 1982).
- Supports word recognition through discrete levels of processing, backed by studies in cerebral processing, indicating different brain regions activate for different word processing stages (Harley, 2008; Petersen et al., 1988; Posner et al., 1988, 1989).
- Word and pseudo word-superiority effects observed in experiments, demonstrating letters are identified more accurately within words or pronounceable pseudowords (Harm & Seidenberg, 2004).
- Lexical-decision tasks used to observe the word-superiority effect, showing higher accuracy in identifying letters within the context of words (Johnston & McClelland, 1973).
- Sentence-superiority effect: words are read faster within sentences, illustrating the importance of context for word recognition (Cattell, 1886; Perfetti, 1985).
- Context effects operate both consciously and preconsciously, aiding in quicker lexical decisions for associated word pairs (e.g., "doctor" and "nurse") (Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; Schvaneveldt et al., 1976).
also put a short example in front of each bullet point,(after each point) in parentheses

- Lexical access is important for reading, allowing the retrieval of a word's meaning from memory. (E.g., Recognizing the word "apple" and recalling its meaning.)
- Interactive process: combines information from letter features, letters, and words. (E.g., Seeing the shape of "A", recognizing it, and connecting it to "APPLE".) (Morton, 1969).
- Interactive-activation model: suggests multiple levels of lexical activation – feature, letter, and word levels. This process is bidirectional, encompassing both bottom-up (sensory data to cognition) and top-down (prior knowledge and context) processing. (E.g., Identifying "cat" starts with recognizing letters C-A-T, then using prior knowledge of the animal.) (McClelland et al., 2009; Rumelhart & McClelland, 1981, 1982).
- Supports word recognition through discrete levels of processing, backed by studies in cerebral processing, indicating different brain regions activate for different word processing stages. (E.g., One brain region processes the shape of words, another their meaning.) (Harley, 2008; Petersen et al., 1988; Posner et al., 1988, 1989).
- Word and pseudo word-superiority effects observed in experiments, demonstrating letters are identified more accurately within words or pronounceable pseudowords. (E.g., Recognizing "word" faster than "wrod" or random letters.) (Harm & Seidenberg, 2004).
- Lexical-decision tasks used to observe the word-superiority effect, showing higher accuracy in identifying letters within the context of words. (E.g., Easier to identify "S" in "SAND" than when it's alone.) (Johnston & McClelland, 1973).
- Sentence-superiority effect: words are read faster within sentences, illustrating the importance of context for word recognition. (E.g., "The sky is blue" is read faster than the same words scrambled without sentence structure.) (Cattell, 1886; Perfetti, 1985).
- Context effects operate both consciously and preconsciously, aiding in quicker lexical decisions for associated word pairs. (E.g., Faster recognition of "nurse" after seeing "doctor" due to association.) (Meyer & Schvaneveldt, 1971; Schvaneveldt et al., 1976).

We have discovered 20 genes belonging to the AA9 family in the genome of T. fergusii.   Phylogenetic study indicated that TfAA9 could be categorised into three subgroups, namely LPMOs1, LPMOs2, and LPMOs3. The gene structure demonstrated a high degree of consistency across the three groups. Analysis of multicollinearity indicated a high degree of orthology between many genes in C. thermophilum and N. crassa. Furthermore, the protein-protein interaction network of TfAA9 with M. thermophila AA9 proteins demonstrates that these proteins share a common features. Furthermore, the regulation of transcript expression and optimisation of enzymatic activity in TfAA9 genes might be influenced by multiple factors, such as endoglucanase and cellulase. Using transcrip expression data from growth on Avicel, cellobiose and glucose we concluded that the fungus relies on an LPMO-centered strategy when grown on cellulosic substrates. The current study reveals a wide range of genes that encode proteins containing the AA9 domain in the genome of T. fergusii.   The present data augment our comprehension of the diversity of fungal AA9 genes, particularly in relation to variations in the mechanisms of cellulose degradation. Conducting more enzymological investigations, heterologous expression in model organism, and comparing their activity and optimal circumstances would offer valuable understanding of the functions of seemingly essential enzymes, such as the AA9 LPMO genes that are expressed at high levels. Boosting the activity and stability of enzymes that degrade biomass can improve the process of substrate saccharification, resulting in heightened efficiency in biorefineries and rendering them economically feasible. Thermothelomyces fergusii genome encodes 20 lipid polysaccharide monooxygenases  (LPMOs) auxiliary activity 9 (AA9) family genes. A comprehensive insight into the gene expression mechanisms regulating the lignocellulolytic machinery in this fungus has yet to be established. Therefore, the comprehensive assay was established to explore the genomic structure, protein-protein interaction, protein orthology, gene ontology, lignocellulolytic degrading pathway, the influence of carbon source on the transcript expression, and enzymatic regulation. TfAA9 was categorized into three subgroups, namely LPMOs1, LPMOs2, and LPMOs3, based on protein structural diversity. Protein-protein interaction analysis revealed that 12 proteins interacted strongly with the Myceliophthora thermophila AA9 proteins network. Gene ontology analysis explained that TfAA9 genes were highly enriched in cellulase activity. Kegg pathways analysis found that TfAA9 proteins act as Endohydrolysis of 1,4-beta-D-glucosidic linkages in cellulose. Here, we show that many TfAA9 gene transcript expression level was up-regulated on avicel, cellobiose, and glucose but the ratio of up-regulated genes was higher on avicel. Similarly, the level of protein concentration, endoglucanase, and cellulase activity was boosted on avicel also. Although T. fergusii genome encodes abundant AA9 LPMOs, poor biomass was observed on avicel. These findings expand our understanding of fungal AA9 genes and their role in lignocellulolytic degradation. The genome and expression analysis of T. fergusii indicates the unique enzymes that the fungus exploits to degrade lignocellulosic materials. The discrepancy in biomass and enzymatic activity suggests screening the TfAA9 gene for its high enzymatic activity and redundant genes via heterologous expression and functional characterization aimed at improving the process of industrial raw material saccharification.

Summarize the following text in max 20 bullet points:

The Bitter Lesson


Rich Sutton


March 13, 2019


 The biggest lesson that can be read from 70 years of AI research is that general methods that leverage computation are ultimately the most effective, and by a large margin. The ultimate reason for this is Moore's law, or rather its generalization of continued exponentially falling cost per unit of computation. Most AI research has been conducted as if the computation available to the agent were constant (in which case leveraging human knowledge would be one of the only ways to improve performance) but, over a slightly longer time than a typical research project, massively more computation inevitably becomes available. Seeking an improvement that makes a difference in the shorter term, researchers seek to leverage their human knowledge of the domain, but the only thing that matters in the long run is the leveraging of computation. These two need not run counter to each other, but in practice they tend to. Time spent on one is time not spent on the other. There are psychological commitments to investment in one approach or the other. And the human-knowledge approach tends to complicate methods in ways that make them less suited to taking advantage of general methods leveraging computation.  There were many examples of AI researchers' belated learning of this bitter lesson, and it is instructive to review some of the most prominent.

 In computer chess, the methods that defeated the world champion, Kasparov, in 1997, were based on massive, deep search. At the time, this was looked upon with dismay by the majority of computer-chess researchers who had pursued methods that leveraged human understanding of the special structure of chess. When a simpler, search-based approach with special hardware and software proved vastly more effective, these human-knowledge-based chess researchers were not good losers. They said that ``brute force" search may have won this time, but it was not a general strategy, and anyway it was not how people played chess. These researchers wanted methods based on human input to win and were disappointed when they did not.

 A similar pattern of research progress was seen in computer Go, only delayed by a further 20 years. Enormous initial efforts went into avoiding search by taking advantage of human knowledge, or of the special features of the game, but all those efforts proved irrelevant, or worse, once search was applied effectively at scale. Also important was the use of learning by self play to learn a value function (as it was in many other games and even in chess, although learning did not play a big role in the 1997 program that first beat a world champion). Learning by self play, and learning in general, is like search in that it enables massive computation to be brought to bear. Search and learning are the two most important classes of techniques for utilizing massive amounts of computation in AI research. In computer Go, as in computer chess, researchers' initial effort was directed towards utilizing human understanding (so that less search was needed) and only much later was much greater success had by embracing search and learning.

 In speech recognition, there was an early competition, sponsored by DARPA, in the 1970s. Entrants included a host of special methods that took advantage of human knowledge---knowledge of words, of phonemes, of the human vocal tract, etc. On the other side were newer methods that were more statistical in nature and did much more computation, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs). Again, the statistical methods won out over the human-knowledge-based methods. This led to a major change in all of natural language processing, gradually over decades, where statistics and computation came to dominate the field. The recent rise of deep learning in speech recognition is the most recent step in this consistent direction. Deep learning methods rely even less on human knowledge, and use even more computation, together with learning on huge training sets, to produce dramatically better speech recognition systems. As in the games, researchers always tried to make systems that worked the way the researchers thought their own minds worked---they tried to put that knowledge in their systems---but it proved ultimately counterproductive, and a colossal waste of researcher's time, when, through Moore's law, massive computation became available and a means was found to put it to good use.

 In computer vision, there has been a similar pattern. Early methods conceived of vision as searching for edges, or generalized cylinders, or in terms of SIFT features. But today all this is discarded. Modern deep-learning neural networks use only the notions of convolution and certain kinds of invariances, and perform much better.

 This is a big lesson. As a field, we still have not thoroughly learned it, as we are continuing to make the same kind of mistakes. To see this, and to effectively resist it, we have to understand the appeal of these mistakes. We have to learn the bitter lesson that building in how we think we think does not work in the long run. The bitter lesson is based on the historical observations that 1) AI researchers have often tried to build knowledge into their agents, 2) this always helps in the short term, and is personally satisfying to the researcher, but 3) in the long run it plateaus and even inhibits further progress, and 4) breakthrough progress eventually arrives by an opposing approach based on scaling computation by search and learning. The eventual success is tinged with bitterness, and often incompletely digested, because it is success over a favored, human-centric approach. 

 One thing that should be learned from the bitter lesson is the great power of general purpose methods, of methods that continue to scale with increased computation even as the available computation becomes very great. The two methods that seem to scale arbitrarily in this way are search and learning. 

 The second general point to be learned from the bitter lesson is that the actual contents of minds are tremendously, irredeemably complex; we should stop trying to find simple ways to think about the contents of minds, such as simple ways to think about space, objects, multiple agents, or symmetries. All these are part of the arbitrary, intrinsically-complex, outside world. They are not what should be built in, as their complexity is endless; instead we should build in only the meta-methods that can find and capture this arbitrary complexity. Essential to these methods is that they can find good approximations, but the search for them should be by our methods, not by us. We want AI agents that can discover like we can, not which contain what we have discovered. Building in our discoveries only makes it harder to see how the discovering process can be done.

- AI research spanning 70 years shows that leveraging computation is most effective.
- This trend is supported by exponentially decreasing costs of computation (Moore's law).
- Historically, AI researchers tried to embed human knowledge into AI to improve performance.
- With more computation over time, methods relying on sheer computational power prevail.
- In computer chess, massive search defeated Kasparov in 1997, outperforming human-knowledge-based algorithms.
- Experts who favored human-like approaches resisted this brute force method, emphasizing general strategy and human play patterns.
- The pattern repeated in computer Go, delayed by 20 years; here, search and self-play learning eventually led to success.
- DARPA's 1970s speech recognition competition showed statistical methods with more computation outperformed human-knowledge-based methods.
- This competition influenced all of natural language processing, shifting towards statistical computation.
- Deep learning in speech recognition further emphasizes reliance on massive computation and large training sets.
- In computer vision, edge detection and feature extraction methods were superseded by deep-learning networks focusing on convolution and invariance.
- The field hasn't fully absorbed this lesson, often repeating the mistake of building in human-like knowledge.
- AI should not be built on how humans think; such embedded knowledge doesn’t scale well in the long term.
- Scaling computation with search and learning methods leads to breakthroughs, despite resistance.
- General methods that utilize increasing computational power—search and learning—are vitally powerful.
- The true complexity of minds and their contents is vast and not fit to be hardcoded into AI.
- Simple internal representations of complex external elements (space, objects, etc.) should be avoided.
- AI should incorporate meta-methods capable of learning and discovering complexities autonomously.
- Building in human discoveries may hinder understanding and development of autonomous discovering processes.
- The overarching message is to design AI to learn and compute at scale, not replicate human thought processes.

Entrants included a host of special methods that took advantage of human knowledge—knowledge of words, of phonemes, of the human vocal tract, etc. On the other side were newer methods that were more statistical in nature and did much more computation, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs). Again, the statistical methods won out over the human-knowledge-based methods. This led to a major change in all of natural language processing, gradually over decades, where statistics and computation came to dominate the field. The recent rise of deep learning in speech recognition is the most recent step in this consistent direction. Deep learning methods rely even less on human knowledge, and use even more computation, together with learning on huge training sets, to produce dramatically better speech recognition systems. As in the games, researchers always tried to make systems that worked the way the researchers thought their own minds worked—they tried to put that knowledge in their systems—but it proved ultimately counterproductive, and a colossal waste of researcher’s time, when, through Moore’s law, massive computation became available and a means was found to put it to good use.

In computer vision, there has been a similar pattern. Early methods conceived of vision as searching for edges, or generalized cylinders, or in terms of SIFT features. But today all this is discarded. Modern deep-learning neural networks use only the notions of convolution and certain kinds of invariances, and perform much better.

This is a big lesson. As a field, we still have not thoroughly learned it, as we are continuing to make the same kind of mistakes. To see this, and to effectively resist it, we have to understand the appeal of these mistakes. We have to learn the bitter lesson that building in how we think we think does not work in the long run. The bitter lesson is based on the historical observations that 1) AI researchers have often tried to build knowledge into their agents, 2) this always helps in the short term, and is personally satisfying to the researcher, but 3) in the long run it plateaus and even inhibits further progress, and 4) breakthrough progress eventually arrives by an opposing approach based on scaling computation by search and learning. The eventual success is tinged with bitterness, and often incompletely digested, because it is success over a favored, human-centric approach. 

One thing that should be learned from the bitter lesson is the great power of general purpose methods, of methods that continue to scale with increased computation even as the available computation becomes very great. The two methods that seem to scale arbitrarily in this way are search and learning. 

The second general point to be learned from the bitter lesson is that the actual contents of minds are tremendously, irredeemably complex; we should stop trying to find simple ways to think about the contents of minds, such as simple ways to think about space, objects, multiple agents, or symmetries. All these are part of the arbitrary, intrinsically-complex, outside world. They are not what should be built in, as their complexity is endless; instead we should build in only the meta-methods that can find and capture this arbitrary complexity. Essential to these methods is that they can find good approximations, but the search for them should be by our methods, not by us. We want AI agents that can discover like we can, not which contain what we have discovered. Building in our discoveries only makes it harder to see how the discovering process can be done.

- AI research over 70 years shows that methods relying on computational power significantly outperform those based on human knowledge, a lesson highlighted by the success of algorithms in chess, Go, speech recognition, and computer vision, and reinforced by the continuous reduction in computation costs as per Moore's law.
- The "bitter lesson" underlines the need to focus on scalable search and learning as general-purpose methods and avoid hardcoding complex, human-like reasoning, which although initially satisfying, ultimately limits the potential for AI systems to autonomously learn and discover the complexities of the world.

Summarize the following text in max 1 bullet points:

The Bitter Lesson


Rich Sutton


March 13, 2019


The biggest lesson that can be read from 70 years of AI research is that general methods that leverage computation are ultimately the most effective, and by a large margin. The ultimate reason for this is Moore’s law, or rather its generalization of continued exponentially falling cost per unit of computation. Most AI research has been conducted as if the computation available to the agent were constant (in which case leveraging human knowledge would be one of the only ways to improve performance) but, over a slightly longer time than a typical research project, massively more computation inevitably becomes available. Seeking an improvement that makes a difference in the shorter term, researchers seek to leverage their human knowledge of the domain, but the only thing that matters in the long run is the leveraging of computation. These two need not run counter to each other, but in practice they tend to. Time spent on one is time not spent on the other. There are psychological commitments to investment in one approach or the other. And the human-knowledge approach tends to complicate methods in ways that make them less suited to taking advantage of general methods leveraging computation. There were many examples of AI researchers’ belated learning of this bitter lesson, and it is instructive to review some of the most prominent.

In computer chess, the methods that defeated the world champion, Kasparov, in 1997, were based on massive, deep search. At the time, this was looked upon with dismay by the majority of computer-chess researchers who had pursued methods that leveraged human understanding of the special structure of chess. When a simpler, search-based approach with special hardware and software proved vastly more effective, these human-knowledge-based chess researchers were not good losers. They said that ``brute force" search may have won this time, but it was not a general strategy, and anyway it was not how people played chess. These researchers wanted methods based on human input to win and were disappointed when they did not.

A similar pattern of research progress was seen in computer Go, only delayed by a further 20 years. Enormous initial efforts went into avoiding search by taking advantage of human knowledge, or of the special features of the game, but all those efforts proved irrelevant, or worse, once search was applied effectively at scale. Also important was the use of learning by self play to learn a value function (as it was in many other games and even in chess, although learning did not play a big role in the 1997 program that first beat a world champion). Learning by self play, and learning in general, is like search in that it enables massive computation to be brought to bear. Search and learning are the two most important classes of techniques for utilizing massive amounts of computation in AI research. In computer Go, as in computer chess, researchers’ initial effort was directed towards utilizing human understanding (so that less search was needed) and only much later was much greater success had by embracing search and learning.

In speech recognition, there was an early competition, sponsored by DARPA, in the 1970s. Entrants included a host of special methods that took advantage of human knowledge—knowledge of words, of phonemes, of the human vocal tract, etc. On the other side were newer methods that were more statistical in nature and did much more computation, based on hidden Markov models (HMMs). Again, the statistical methods won out over the human-knowledge-based methods. This led to a major change in all of natural language processing, gradually over decades, where statistics and computation came to dominate the field. The recent rise of deep learning in speech recognition is the most recent step in this consistent direction. Deep learning methods rely even less on human knowledge, and use even more computation, together with learning on huge training sets, to produce dramatically better speech recognition systems. As in the games, researchers always tried to make systems that worked the way the researchers thought their own minds worked—they tried to put that knowledge in their systems—but it proved ultimately counterproductive, and a colossal waste of researcher’s time, when, through Moore’s law, massive computation became available and a means was found to put it to good use.

In computer vision, there has been a similar pattern. Early methods conceived of vision as searching for edges, or generalized cylinders, or in terms of SIFT features. But today all this is discarded. Modern deep-learning neural networks use only the notions of convolution and certain kinds of invariances, and perform much better.

This is a big lesson. As a field, we still have not thoroughly learned it, as we are continuing to make the same kind of mistakes. To see this, and to effectively resist it, we have to understand the appeal of these mistakes. We have to learn the bitter lesson that building in how we think we think does not work in the long run. The bitter lesson is based on the historical observations that 1) AI researchers have often tried to build knowledge into their agents, 2) this always helps in the short term, and is personally satisfying to the researcher, but 3) in the long run it plateaus and even inhibits further progress, and 4) breakthrough progress eventually arrives by an opposing approach based on scaling computation by search and learning. The eventual success is tinged with bitterness, and often incompletely digested, because it is success over a favored, human-centric approach. 

One thing that should be learned from the bitter lesson is the great power of general purpose methods, of methods that continue to scale with increased computation even as the available computation becomes very great. The two methods that seem to scale arbitrarily in this way are search and learning. 

The second general point to be learned from the bitter lesson is that the actual contents of minds are tremendously, irredeemably complex; we should stop trying to find simple ways to think about the contents of minds, such as simple ways to think about space, objects, multiple agents, or symmetries. All these are part of the arbitrary, intrinsically-complex, outside world. They are not what should be built in, as their complexity is endless; instead we should build in only the meta-methods that can find and capture this arbitrary complexity. Essential to these methods is that they can find good approximations, but the search for them should be by our methods, not by us. We want AI agents that can discover like we can, not which contain what we have discovered. Building in our discoveries only makes it harder to see how the discovering process can be done.

- Seventy years of AI research converge on a "bitter lesson": scalable computational methods outpace those embedded with human knowledge, suggesting that future AI should harness search and learning for tackling complex tasks rather than relying on human-like reasoning.
What has Jürgen Schmidthuber to say on this subject?

Jürgen Schmidhuber, a prominent figure in the field of artificial intelligence and deep learning, has contributed to the discussion on the efficacy of leveraging computation over infusing human knowledge into AI systems. Although I can't provide a current statement from him on Rich Sutton's "The Bitter Lesson," Schmidhuber's research and work generally align with the ideas of scaling computation and the importance of learning algorithms.

Schmidhuber has been a proponent of neural networks and their ability to learn from large amounts of data, suggesting that as computational resources grow, so does the potential of AI systems to learn independently of human-designed features. He has heavily contributed to the development of methods in neural networks and deep learning, including the foundational work on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, which are a type of recurrent neural network capable of learning long-term dependencies.

Schmidhuber's work supports the idea that machine learning models, which can improve and adapt through experience (data), are critical to achieving general AI. By extension, this lines up with the sentiment that general methods leveraging computation are ultimately more effective in the long run, a key point in Sutton's "The Bitter Lesson."

For Schmidhuber's specific thoughts on this matter, one would need to look at his latest papers, talks, and interviews for direct commentary.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), a novel type of battery technology, offer numerous advantages such as high energy density and low cost, positioning them as promising alternatives to lithium-ion batteries for energy storage. Despite their potential, the capacity and cycling stability of SIBs are still in the early stages of research and require further improvement. Consequently, the establishment of heterostructures has surfaced as an effective strategy for augmenting the cycling stability and rate characteristics of the electrodes. This study investigates the application of V1.13Se2/V2O3 heterostructure materials in SIBs, which were prepared using a straightforward one-step solid-state sintering method. Notably, the V1.13Se2/V2O3 heterostructure exhibits remarkable properties, including a capacity of 328.5 mAh g-1 even after 1500 cycles at a high current density of 2 A g-1, and a rate capability of 278.9 mAh g-1 at 5 A g-1, owing to its high pseudocapacitance and low characteristic relaxation time constant. These findings offer valuable insights and guidance for the rapid synthesis of heterojunction materials and the advancement of SIBs.

Based on the two news summaries provided, it is evident that the "Good Ones" summary is better than the "Bad Ones" summary. The reasons why the "Good Ones" summary is better are as follows:

1. Comprehensive Coverage: The "Good Ones" summary covers multiple news items, including the US macro data, Fitch downgrade of the US, Macau's gaming revenue, and China's EV sales. This breadth of coverage provides a holistic view of different sectors and regions, offering readers a more complete understanding of the current events.

2. In-depth Information: The "Good Ones" summary provides specific details and figures to support the news. For instance, it mentions the ISM manufacturing index, employment figures, job openings, as well as specific numbers related to Macau's gaming industry and EV sales. This level of detail makes the news more informative and engaging for the readers.

3. Context and Analysis: The "Good Ones" summary incorporates contextual information and analysis to give readers a better understanding of the news. For example, it mentions the reasons behind the Fitch downgrade of the US, highlights the performance drivers in Macau's gaming industry, and discusses the positive signs in the EV sector. This analysis helps readers interpret the news and its implications correctly.

Guidelines for Writing News Summaries:

1. Be comprehensive: Include all relevant news items within a specific context or theme. This helps readers grasp the bigger picture and understand the interconnectedness of different events.

2. Provide factual details: Include specific figures, statistics, and data to support the news. This adds credibility to the summary and allows readers to verify the information if needed.

3. Add analysis and context: Provide additional information or analysis to help readers understand the implications or significance of the news. This adds value and depth to the summary, allowing readers to form a well-informed opinion.

4. Be concise: Summarize news items succinctly without sacrificing clarity. Focus on the key points and use precise language to convey the essential information effectively.

5. Be objective: Present the news in an unbiased manner, avoiding personal opinions or subjective language. Stick to the facts and let the readers draw their own conclusions from the information provided.

By adhering to these guidelines, news summaries can become informative, engaging, and valuable resources for readers seeking a quick overview of current events.
can you sum up the important elements of writing news summary

Certainly! Here are the important elements to consider when writing a news summary:

1. Conciseness: Summarize the news using clear and concise language. Focus on conveying key information without unnecessary detail or repetition.

2. Relevance: Include only the most important and relevant details of the news. Understand the central theme or topic and select information that directly contributes to the understanding of that topic.

3. Objectivity: Maintain an objective and neutral tone. Present the facts without personal bias or subjective opinions.

4. Accuracy: Ensure the accuracy of the information presented in the summary. Verify facts and cross-reference multiple sources if necessary.

5. Clarity: Use straightforward and easily understandable language. Avoid jargon or technical terms unless they are essential to the understanding of the news.

6. Context: Provide relevant background information or context to aid readers in understanding the news. Explain the significance or implications of the events whenever possible.

7. Structure: Organize the news summary in a logical and coherent manner. Start with a clear headline or introduction, followed by the main points or key details, and conclude with a concise summary or takeaway.

8. Balance: Strive for balance by representing different perspectives or sides of the story, if applicable. Present a fair and comprehensive view of the news.

9. Credibility: Attribute information to reliable sources and cite them appropriately. Use reputable sources to enhance the credibility of the news summary.

10. Engagement: Aim to engage readers with informative and interesting content. Use compelling language and storytelling techniques, when appropriate, to grab readers' attention and maintain their interest.

Whether the impairment of consciousness should be the excuse for reducing a sentence?

Notably, in 2020, the notorious child rapist Cho Doo-Soon was released after 12 years in jail. The court sentence led to the eruption of public anger in Korean society since he kidnapped and assaulted an eight-year-old girl, Na-young. More than 600,000 people signed a petition on the presidential Blue House's website, calling for a retrial and arguing against admitting him back to society. But the government has refused. (William Lee,2021) Originally, he was sentenced to 15 years of imprisonment. However, his punishment was reduced to only 12 years because he claimed he drank too much alcohol. At this point, public citizens questioned whether this could be a compelling justification. This essay will discuss whether and when the impairment of mental state should be an excuse for reducing a sentence.
 
To commence with, the impairment of consciousness should be considered a compelling reason for reducing punishment in some typical circumstances. Widely accepted theories for crime constitution like “Four elements crime constitution theory” (Yanan Shi, 2015) or “three class theory” (Xingliang Chen, 2022) both include conditions related to “moral culpability”. To be more specific, according to the School Professor of Law, Gender and Social Policy at LSE, Nicola Lacey, “It is only legitimate to hold people criminally responsible for things which they had the capacity to avoid doing”. (Nicola Lacey, 2016) This condition is listed together with legal culpability, which means “the person admits to having engaged – or it is proved that they engaged – in the prohibited conduct” (Nicola Lacey, 2016) as requirements that must be met for conviction. Hence, two categories of impairment of consciousness should be discussed separately. The first is that the criminals’ consciousness is deeply affected by mental illness, which is not caused by criminals themselves. In Brown v The Queen, according to the forensic psychiatrist Andrew Carroll, the criminal’s arson offenses are motivated by her will to return to custody because her mental illness stopped her from stepping into society and affected her cognition about the result of this offense.(Chris Maxwell,2023) The court accepted her reasoning that her mental illness  “significantly impaired her judgment” and “fundamentally impaired her ability to act rationally, regulate her conduct and fully understand the consequences” and made her release as long as there is consistent support and a real level of supervision.( SUPREME COURT OF VICTORIA
COURT OF APPEAL, 2020)
 
Moreover, if the criminals’ impairment of consciousness is caused by their own intents, the sentence will not be shortened. For example, in Wright v The Queen ([2015] VSCA333), the appellant Jesse Wright stopped taking psychoactive drugs voluntarily without consent from the doctor. What’s more, he restarted taking methamphetamine, which caused his schizophrenia. He committed a series of thefts in July and August 2013. On 19 August 2013, he “indecently assaulted” a 16-year-old girl in her bedroom, and on 19 and 20 April, he stole 15 pairs of women’s underwear and five bras. Soon after he assaulted a woman in 2014, He was sentenced to 11 years and 3 months of imprisonment, with a non-parole period of 8 years and 6 months (Chris Maxwell,2023). Although he was deeply affected by his mental illness when committing the crime, his appeal for reducing a sentence was rejected since his actions of stopping the medication and restarting taking methamphetamine are voluntary and are direct causes of his mental illness. In fact, the crime could have been avoided. Hence, drug-taking and stopping medications were the chief factors of his crime.

Yet, some critics may claim that accepting this will let off some horrible criminals. Actually, this view is untenable since the Cho Doo-Soon case demonstrates that the Korean jurisdiction system has loopholes. Cho’s decreasing level of consciousness is caused by his drunkenness. Also, he tortured the victim with water cannon to destroy evidence and “leaving around 80 percent of her lower organs completely dysfunctional” (Jeon Tae-Gyu, Shim Kyu-Seok, 2020). Apparently, Cho has a very clear sense of consciousness since he carefully planned each procedure of his offense and he knew that he would be seriously punished. According to Chris, “evidence of intricate planning and management” helps determine how much mental dysfunction affects. This demonstrates that Cho Doo-Soon should not be commuted for drinking. 
 
In short, based on the preceding analysis, the impairment of consciousness should be eligible for reducing a sentence as long as the requirements in conviction theories are satisfied. Nevertheless, it could not be an excuse if criminals voluntarily cause the impairing consciousness.

Here are some suggested edits to improve the clarity and flow of your writing:

Title suggestion: "Reducing a Sentence Due to Impairment of Consciousness: When is it Justifiable?"

Notably, in 2020, notorious child rapist Cho Doo-Soon was released after serving 12 years in jail. This court decision led to public outcry in Korean society as Cho had kidnapped and assaulted an eight-year-old girl. More than 600,000 people signed a petition calling for a retrial and opposing his reentry into society; however, the government rejected their appeal (William Lee, 2021). Cho's sentence was reduced from the original 15 years because he claimed he drank too much alcohol. This incident raises the question of whether impairment of consciousness should serve as a valid excuse for reducing a sentence. This essay discusses the circumstances under which this should be permissible.

To begin with, impairment of consciousness may be a valid justification for reducing punishment in certain cases. The "Four elements crime constitution theory" (Yanan Shi, 2015) and the "three class theory" (Xingliang Chen, 2022) both emphasize the importance of "moral culpability" in crime. This refers to the notion that people should only be held criminally responsible for things within their control (Nicola Lacey, 2016). Legal culpability, which refers to whether there is proof of a prohibited conduct or confession by the accused, is also a requirement for conviction. Therefore, different types of impairment should be assessed separately.  

Firstly, if a criminal's impairment of consciousness is due to an illness not caused by themselves, it may reduce their level of culpability. In Brown v The Queen, the forensic psychiatrist Andrew Carroll argued that a woman's conviction for arson was influenced by a desire to return to custody, as her mental illness prevented her from adjusting to society and impaired her ability to rationalize her actions (Chris Maxwell, 2023). The court accepted her argument, stating that she was not fully responsible for her actions due to her illness and reduced her sentence. However, her release was only granted with proper support and supervision.

On the other hand, if a criminal causes their own impairment of consciousness, their sentence should not be reduced. Wright v The Queen ([2015] VSCA333) is a case in point: the appellant, Jesse Wright, stopped taking psychoactive drugs without a doctor's consent, which led to his schizophrenia. He proceeded to commit thefts and sexual assault. Despite his mental illness, his appeal to reduce his sentence was denied since he voluntarily stopped his medication and resumed drug-taking, which directly caused his mental impairment. In essence, his criminal actions could have been averted. 

Some critics may argue that allowing reduction of sentence due to impairment of consciousness lets dangerous criminals off the hook. However, the case of Cho Doo-Soon demonstrates flaws in the Korean legal system. Cho's impairment of consciousness resulted from his drunkenness, and his crime was premeditated with torture of the victim to destroy evidence. He was fully aware of the severity of his actions and should not have received a reduced sentence based on his claim of excessive drinking. 

In conclusion, impairment of consciousness can serve as a valid reason to reduce a sentence if it aligns with conviction theories and the criminal did not cause it voluntarily. However, this must be assessed on a case-by-case basis to ensure that dangerous criminals do not receive undue leniency.

Mg is easier to precipitate than Ca in arid climates (Billups and Schrag, 2003; Peng et al., 2021), which may impact Ca precipitation, in turn influencing the Mg

I want you to act as an academic journal editor. Your task is to follow the Reviewer Comment to rewrite the conclusion of a paper.
--------------------
OLD CONCLUSION
Extreme precipitation events influenced by ENSO serve as the critical pathway by which ENSO impacts the worldwide climate. Specifically, the tropical Pacific precipitation induced by ENSO has the potential to trigger extreme weather occurrences globally, leading to substantial harm to agriculture, ecosystems, and economic stability. However, existing spatiotemporal clustering algorithms face challenges in effectively identifying rapidly changing sea surface precipitation anomaly variations. To address this issue, this paper proposes an object-oriented spatiotemporal clustering algorithm using raster (OSCAR) that can effectively identify precipitation anomaly variation patterns. The OSCAR was validated using simulated datasets and applied to identify sea surface precipitation anomaly variations during typical ENSO events in tropical Pacific. The relationship between these variations and ENSO events was analyzed. The main work in this paper is as follows: 
(1) Design of Spatiotemporal clustering algorithm 
A spatiotemporal clustering algorithm called Object-oriented Spatiotemporal Clustering Algorithm based Raster (OSCAR) is proposed to identify precipitation anomaly variations based on their evolution characteristics. The proposed algorithm involves a two-step approach, where spatial clustering is first performed on raster pixels of each timestamp to obtain segment objects. Subsequently, similar segments of adjacent timestamps are clustered to ensure the spatial consistency at each timestamp and the temporal continuity of spatiotemporal clusters. 
(2) Validation of Spatiotemporal clustering algorithm 
The OSCAR is validated using simulated datasets and compared with traditional DcSTCA. The results of the experiment show that OSCAR is more effective in identifying rapidly changing precipitation anomaly variations compared to DcSTCA. Additionally, the OSCAR exhibits higher accuracy than the DcSTCA, as evidenced by improvements in the ARI and NMI index of the clustering results from 0.88 and 0.81 to 0.95 and 0.91, respectively. This validation study demonstrates the effectiveness of OSCAR in identifying spatiotemporal clustering patterns of precipitation anomaly variations.
(3) Application of sea surface precipitation anomaly variations 
The OSCAR is utilized to the spatiotemporal clustering of ENSO-related sea surface precipitation anomaly in the tropical Pacific region. The experiment results indicate 2 key points. Firstly, positive anomaly clusters occur in the central-eastern tropical Pacific during El Niño events, while negative anomaly clusters occur in the western-central tropical Pacific during La Niña events. Secondly, the positive or negative anomalies enhance with El Niño or La Niña events. Previous research has demonstrated that during El Niño events (e.g., 2015), warm sea temperature anomalies result in increased precipitation in the central tropical Pacific Ocean; conversely, during La Niña events (e.g., 2010), negative precipitation anomalies coexist with low sea temperature anomalies in the central and western tropical Pacific Ocean [4, 16, 33]. The spatiotemporal clustering results presented in this study are comparable to the previous research based on static statistical values within a specific time frame. This illustrates the effectiveness of the OSCAR in detecting the evolution of ENSO-related precipitation anomalies, which may provide valuable reference for understanding the feedback and driving mechanism between tropical Pacific precipitation and ENSO.

All authors have read and agreed to the published version of the manuscript.
-----------------------
COMMENT
The conclusion should not be repeat of the works of this study. But the state the most important outcome of your work, i.e. interpret your findings at a higher level of abstraction. Yet add some perspectives.
-----------------------
New conclusion is

NEW CONCLUSION

Extreme precipitation events influenced by ENSO significantly impact the global climate, posing substantial risks to agriculture, ecosystems, and economic stability. The robust identification of rapidly changing sea surface precipitation anomaly variations remains a challenge with existing spatiotemporal clustering algorithms. In this paper, we introduced an Object-oriented Spatiotemporal Clustering Algorithm using Raster (OSCAR) designed to effectively identify precipitation anomaly variation patterns and applied it to analyze ENSO events in the tropical Pacific.

Our study revealed two critical insights: firstly, OSCAR outperforms traditional DcSTCA in identifying rapidly changing precipitation anomaly variations, as evidenced by higher accuracy measures (improvements in ARI and NMI indexes); secondly, using OSCAR to analyze ENSO-related sea surface precipitation anomalies led to results consistent with previous research based on static statistical values. Moreover, our findings illustrated that the positive and negative anomaly clusters during El Niño and La Niña events, respectively, are not only localized but also intensify with the worsening of these events.

By offering an effective method for detecting the evolution of ENSO-related precipitation anomalies, our study contributes to the understanding of the feedback and driving mechanisms between tropical Pacific precipitation and ENSO. This knowledge is invaluable for mitigating the adverse effects of extreme climate events on a global scale. In future research, the application of OSCAR can be extended to other geophysical and environmental domains, providing a valuable tool for monitoring and interpreting complex spatiotemporal phenomena at high levels of abstraction.

The cognitive theory of learning revolves around how people process information and proffer solutions to problems with the use their mental activities (Shuell, 1986). The theory suggests that learning actually occurs in people during the process of acquiring, storing, and retrieving information, as well as transferring knowledge (Richter, 1998). This approach focuses primarily on individuals, including their mental models and behaviour, while downplaying the importance of the surrounding conditions (Brown & Duguid, 1991). There are arguments that this perspective severs individuals from social interactions and conditions (Van Der Sluis & Poell, 2002). The knowledge structures that enable individuals to engage with the world is their mental models, aiding in identifying and remembering relationships, forming future expectations, drawing conclusions, and understanding phenomena (Mathieu et al., 2000). The theory also makes assumptions about the fact that knowledge can be transferred from a particular context to another, which sponsors the conveying of knowledge from program facilitators to individuals or participants who can then recall and apply it in their workplace (Ormrod, 1999). In contrast to the role of the expert in the action learning approach this approach assigns a central role to the expert (MacLaughlin & Thorpe, 1993). The (CLP) cognitive learning perspective facilitates the examination of changes in managers' understanding of transformational leadership and teamwork, as well as their impact on their workplace practices. The success of cognitive learning can be evaluated based on its fundamental assumption.

The cognitive theory of learning centers around how individuals process information and solve problems using their mental activities (Shuell, 1986). According to this theory, learning takes place as people acquire, store, and retrieve information, as well as transfer knowledge (Richter, 1998). This perspective primarily focuses on individuals, including their mental models and behavior, while underplaying the significance of external conditions (Brown & Duguid, 1991). Some argue that this approach separates individuals from social interactions and contexts (Van Der Sluis & Poell, 2002). Mental models, which are knowledge structures that enable individuals to engage with the world, play a key role in identifying and remembering relationships, forming expectations, drawing conclusions, and understanding phenomena (Mathieu et al., 2000). Additionally, the theory assumes that knowledge can be transferred from one context to another, allowing program facilitators to convey knowledge to individuals or participants who can then apply it in their workplace (Ormrod, 1999). In contrast to the action learning approach, the cognitive learning perspective assigns a central role to the expert (MacLaughlin & Thorpe, 1993). The cognitive learning perspective (CLP) facilitates the examination of how managers' understanding of transformational leadership and teamwork changes and how these changes affect their workplace practices. The success of cognitive learning can be assessed based on its fundamental assumption.

Title: Literature Review on Relevant Theories of Reading Comprehension Level

Introduction:
Reading comprehension is a complex cognitive process that involves the interaction of various factors, including text characteristics, reader abilities, and environmental factors. Understanding the theories related to reading comprehension levels is vital for educators and researchers to develop effective instructional strategies and interventions. This literature review aims to critically evaluate the relevant theories of reading comprehension level, with specific attention to studies published after 2014.

1. The Simple View of Reading (SVR):
The Simple View of Reading posits that reading comprehension is influenced by two essential components: decoding (word recognition) and linguistic comprehension (language understanding). According to this theory, reading comprehension level can be determined by the interaction between a reader's decoding skills and linguistic comprehension abilities (Gough & Tunmer, 1986). This theory provides a foundation for understanding the importance of decoding and linguistic comprehension in reading comprehension level.

2. Coherence Theory:
The Coherence Theory explains reading comprehension as the ability to construct a coherent mental representation of the text. It emphasizes the importance of linking ideas, making connections, and identifying relationships within the text. This theory suggests that readers actively create mental models or schemas to develop a coherent understanding of the text, which influences their comprehension level (McNamara, Boone, & McCarthy, 2015).

3. Interactive Compensatory Model:
The Interactive Compensatory Model proposes that reading comprehension involves a simultaneous interaction between lower-level processes (e.g., word recognition) and higher-level cognitive processes (e.g., inference-making). This model suggests that weaker word recognition skills can be compensated for by stronger higher-level cognitive skills, and vice versa. Thus, readers with different profiles of strengths and weaknesses may achieve similar reading comprehension levels through different pathways (Perfetti, Landi, & Oakhill, 2014).

4. Self-Regulated Strategy Development (SRSD) Model:
The SRSD Model emphasizes the importance of self-regulation and strategic use of learning strategies to improve reading comprehension. This model highlights the role of explicit instruction, metacognitive strategy instruction, and self-regulation techniques in enhancing reading comprehension level (Graham & Harris, 2019).

5. Dual Coding Theory:
Dual Coding Theory suggests that reading comprehension can be enhanced by the simultaneous processing of verbal and visual information. This theory emphasizes the use of both linguistic and non-linguistic representations to support comprehension. Integrating visuals with text can enhance understanding, aid in memory retention, and contribute to higher reading comprehension levels (Mayer, 2017).

Conclusion:
Understanding the theories of reading comprehension level is essential for educators, researchers, and professionals in the field of education. The theories reviewed in this paper shed light on the complex processes involved in reading comprehension and offer valuable insights into effective instructional strategies. The Simple View of Reading, Coherence Theory, Interactive Compensatory Model, Self-Regulated Strategy Development Model, and Dual Coding Theory provide a framework for understanding the factors influencing reading comprehension level. Utilizing these theories can enhance instructional practices and support learners in improving their reading comprehension abilities.

References:

Gough, P. B., & Tunmer, W. E. (1986). Decoding, reading, and reading disability. Remedial and Special Education, 7(1), 6-10.

Graham, S., & Harris, K. R. (2019). Principles of Effective Writing Instruction. Encyclopedia of Teacher Education, 1-4.

Mayer, R. E. (2017). Using multimedia for e-learning. Journal of computer assisted learning, 33(5), 403-423.

McNamara, D. S., Boone, A. P., & McCarthy, P. N. (2015). Reading comprehension. Handbook of cognition and education, 267-293.

Perfetti, C. A., Landi, N., & Oakhill, J. (2014). The acquisition of reading comprehension skill. Handbook of reading research, 5, 227-247.

Without content, students may engage in problem-solving or team-working experiences that fall into triviality, into relevance without rigor. But the traditional drug screening protocol is time-consuming, laborious and costly, keeping anti-cancer drug price up and resulting clinical shortage. The traditional drug screening protocol used in systematic research of anti-cancer drugs is known to be time-consuming, laborious, and costly. These factors contribute to the high prices of anti-cancer drugs and result in a shortage in clinical settings. To overcome these challenges, an innovative microfluidic drug screening platform has been developed. This platform integrates three functional models: rapid concentration gradient generation, reliable cancer model construction, and convenient cell viability testing. By leveraging the flexibility of 3D printing technology, a unique spatial channel structure has been fabricated to enhance the mixing effect, resulting in faster generation of concentration gradients compared to current microfluidic generators.

In conclusion, a concentration gradient generator with complex three-dimensional microchannel was developed successfully, which provided an integrated, miniaturized and automated drug screening platform. It was diversely considered to improve working efficiency, reduce experiment cost and has great applied potential through anti-cancer drug research.

In summary, a successful development of a concentration gradient generator with a complex three-dimensional microchannel has led to the creation of an integrated, miniaturized, and automated drug screening platform. This platform is expected to significantly improve working efficiency, reduce experimental costs, and holds great potential for application in anti-cancer drug research.

This study makes use of several primary proxies to assess the alteration of the source-rock profile. These include the Chemical Index of Alteration minus K-potassium index (CIA-K), the Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA), CIA', and CALMAG weathering index values. The use of CALMAG provides a comprehensive approach to evaluating the degree of alteration regarding the relative abundance of all three major cations and presents a standardized framework. As a result, this analysis offers a more integrated perspective on weathering intensity.

The CIA is calculated using molecular proportions, and the formula is CIA = [Al2O3/ (Al2O3 + CaO* + Na2O + K2O)] × 100 (Nesbitt and Young, 1982). The CaO* represents only the fraction present in silicate minerals and serves as a reliable measure of weathering intensity since aluminum content tends to increase with heightened weathering. CIA-K, on the other hand, takes into account the influence of potassium on weathering processes and is particularly useful in assessing feldspar-rich rocks. Finally, CIA' is a modified version of CIA designed specifically for carbonate-dominated lithologies.

The application of these weathering proxies facilitates the evaluation of the degree to which rocks in the source-rock profile have undergone biogeochemical weathering processes. Using these proxies, it is possible to assess the intensity of weathering, which provides important insights into the geological history of the region and influences factors such as erosion and soil formation. By utilizing a standardized framework, the analysis of these weathering proxies offers a more holistic and robust understanding of the degree of alteration in the source-rock, providing valuable scientific knowledge for future research.

The paleo-MAP (over the range of 200mm–1600 mm) can be estimated using the CIA-K proxy (Sheldon et al. 2002; Sheldon and Tabor 2009). These indices were chosen due to their importance in describing weathering processes in soils, and due to their application in common transfer functions for environmental relationships (Table V).The evapotranspiration (ET) was calculated using the equation ET = MAP – Peff (where Peff is the precipitation effective (Gulbranson et al., 2011). The Peff transfer function was calculated using the three transfer functions for the three temperature intervals according to Gulbranson et al. (2011). The energy influx from precipitation (EPPT (kJ m-2 yr-1 )) was calculated using the equation EPPT= [4.18 * ∆T] *[MAP -ET]) where ∆T is the temperature difference between 273.16K and MAT (K) (Gulbranson et al., 2011) The Energy flux from organic matter (Rasmussen et al., 2005; Gulbranson et al., 2011), namely net primary productivity (ENPP) linked to CIA, MAP and ET is calculated using the three-transfer functions according to the three MAT ranges (Gulbranson et al., 2011).

The primary indices utilized in estimating relative humidity and floral regime in correlation with the Holdridge life zones (ET versus Eppt) (Gulbranson et al., 2011 and Holdridge, 1947) are paleo-mean annual precipitation (MAP (cm)), and mean annual temperature (MAT (C°)) (Gallagher and Sheldon, 2013). The paleo-MAP (ranging from 200mm to 1600 mm) can be estimated using the CIA-K proxy (Sheldon et al. 2002; Sheldon and Tabor 2009). The influx of energy from precipitation (EPPT (kJ m-2 yr-1)) is measured using the formula EPPT = [4.18 * ∆T] *[MAP -ET]), with the temperature difference (∆T) between 273.16K and MAT (K) (Gulbranson et al., 2011). The energy from organic matter flux (Rasmussen et al., 2005; Gulbranson et al., 2011), specifically the net primary productivity (ENPP) that is linked to the CIA, MAP, and ET, is calculated by employing the three transfer functions in line with the three MAT ranges (Gulbranson et al., 2011).

The process of estimating relative humidity and floral regime in correlation with the Holdridge life zones (ET versus Eppt) involves the use of two primary proxies, namely paleo-mean annual precipitation (MAP (cm)) and mean annual temperature (MAT (C°)) (Gallagher and Sheldon, 2013). These indices have been selected for their vital contribution in describing the weathering processes in soils and their applications in common transfer functions for environmental relationships (Table V).

To calculate evapotranspiration (ET), the equation ET = MAP – Peff has been employed. Here, Peff signifies the effective value of precipitation (Gulbranson et al., 2011). Meanwhile, estimating the Peff transfer function requires the use of three transfer functions specified in Gulbranson et al. (2011) for different temperature intervals. 

In addition, the influx of energy from precipitation (EPPT (kJ m-2 yr-1)) has been computed using the formula EPPT = [4.18 * ∆T] *[MAP -ET]). The parameter ∆T refers to the temperature difference between 273.16K and MAT (K) (Gulbranson et al., 2011). 

Moreover, the energy from organic matter flux, specifically the net primary productivity (ENPP), which is tightly linked with CIA, MAP, and ET, has also been estimated. The calculation of ENPP has been carried out using the three transfer functions based on the three MAT ranges in Gulbranson et al. (2011). 

Overall, these indices and transfer functions have been carefully selected and employed to estimate relative humidity and floral regime in relation to Holdridge life zones, which can provide valuable insights into the environmental relationships and weathering processes in soils.

The Tundra developed under instable Jurassic climate with perhumid/humid, to superhumid moisture regime and wet- to rain Tundra that persisted throughout the entire period. Cold and frozen landscape characterizes the Tundra biome during most of the year. Tundra occurs in two distinct cold and dry regions. First, nowadays Arctic Tundra are found on high-latitude terranes, above the Arctic Circle (Alaska, Canada, Russia, Greenland, Iceland, and Scandinavia) or on far southern regions of Antarctica.  Second, are Alpine tundra (Thorne, 1987; Walker and Wielgolaski, 2000;Nakamura et al., 1994; 2007) are located atop mountains at very high altitudes, where temperatures fall below freezing by night. Throughout the world, trees are absent in Alpine tundra. In addition, soil in the Alpine Tundra is particularly well drained regarding polar Tundra one. Also, plants are very similar to those of the arctic Tundra. The characteristic of the alpine Tundra (Nakamura et al., 1994, 2007) is similar to polar Tundra in that it has no trees, has annual temperatures that are recorded to be very low. However, unlike the polar Tundra, the Alpine one is characterized by higher annual average precipitations and temperatures. Alpine Tundra areas, particularly in the southern hemisphere and equatorial regions which are considered as fragmented areas compared with the relatively continuous Arctic Tundra (Korner, 1995; Walker, 1999, 2000 and 2001). The Alpine Tundra biome is located at heights above 1200 feet (about 3658m) and above these regions the snow is permanent.

The tundra biome developed under unstable Jurassic climate with a perhumid/humid to superhumid moisture regime, and a wet-to-rain tundra that persisted throughout the entire period. Cold and frozen landscapes characterize the tundra biome for most of the year. Tundra occurs in two distinct cold and dry regions. First, the Arctic tundra can be found on high-latitude terranes above the Arctic Circle (Alaska, Canada, Russia, Greenland, Iceland, and Scandinavia) or on the far southern regions of Antarctica. Second, Alpine tundra is located at the top of mountains at very high altitudes, where temperatures fall below freezing at night. Trees are absent in Alpine tundra throughout the world. Additionally, the soil in Alpine tundra is particularly well-drained compared to that of polar tundra. The plants in Alpine tundra are very similar to those found in the Arctic tundra. The characteristics of Alpine tundra are similar to those of polar tundra in that they have no trees and annual temperatures that are very low. However, unlike polar tundra, Alpine tundra is characterized by higher annual average precipitation and temperatures. Alpine tundra areas, particularly in the southern hemisphere and equatorial regions, are fragmented compared to the relatively continuous Arctic tundra. The Alpine tundra biome is located at heights above 1200 feet (about 3658m), and above these regions, snow is permanent.
