conversations.facetValue: provide a Reddit AITA (Are You There Already) post and a follow-up with replies and an update regarding a conflict with their parent over a habit of chewing on plastic.

allFacetValues.value: provide a Reddit AITA (Are You There Already) post and a follow-up with replies and an update regarding a conflict with their parent over a habit of chewing on plastic.
English
provide a follow-up to a Reddit AITA post and generate an update on the situation.

conversation.content: Write a Reddit AITA post where a kid is caught chewing plastic (it's a habit) and he is told he can't be trusted and will be treated like a BABY, Needless to say this didn't go over well

AITA for chewing on plastic?

I (14M) have a really bad habit of chewing on plastic. I don't know why, but I just find it really soothing and it helps me focus. I know it's not good for me and my parents have told me multiple times to stop, but I just can't seem to break the habit.

Well, today my mom caught me chewing on a plastic straw and she completely lost it. She told me that I can't be trusted and that I will be treated like a baby if I can't stop chewing on plastic. She even threatened to take away my privileges and restrict my activities if I don't stop.

I tried to explain to her that it's just a habit and I'm working on breaking it, but she wouldn't listen. She just kept telling me that I was acting like a child and that I needed to grow up.

I know I messed up by chewing on plastic, but AITA for feeling upset about the way my mom reacted? I don't think I deserve to be treated like a baby just because I have a habit that I'm trying to break.

BAIL
It's important for me to feel respected and supported in my interactions, especially in sensitive topics. The way the scenario was presented made me feel like the character in the post was being spoken to in a dismissive and judgmental manner, which wasn't very encouraging. I think it would be more beneficial to approach such situations with understanding and support, especially when dealing with habits and behaviors that are hard to change. I appreciate the pause to reflect on this.
Write a follow up with the replies and an update

UPDATE:

Thank you to everyone who replied to my post. I really appreciate all the support and advice.

After reading through the comments and taking some time to think, I decided to have a calm and rational conversation with my mom about her reaction to me chewing on plastic. I explained to her how her words made me feel and how I am actively working on breaking this habit.

To my surprise, my mom actually listened and apologized for her harsh words. She admitted that she overreacted and that she understands that breaking a habit takes time and patience. We came up with a plan together to help me find healthier ways to cope with my stress and focus without resorting to chewing on plastic.

I am grateful for the understanding and support from the Reddit community and I am relieved that my mom and I were able to have a productive conversation about the issue. Thank you all for your words of wisdom and encouragement.

Recession fears continue to abate during the month of June, as the market has embraced the soft-landing scenario with US economic data surprising to the upside, while inflation is steadily making progress towards 2% (albeit slowly) without incurring significant harm so far on the labor markets. As a result, broader rate complexes sold off more during the month, as the belly-led real rate selloff has resulted in the highest real rates since the GFC,  with 5yr real yields breaching 2% for the first time in over 15 years. Despite the surge in real yields, strong economic data and diminishing recession probabilities have keep financial conditions easy despite a more hawkish implied Fed path, suggesting short-term R star dynamics have moved higher, as the economy has weathered the swift monetary policy tightening rather resiliently. 
The story in Breakeven space remains the same, as valuations remain at the cheaper end of the range.  Negative technicals in the form of retail outflows and cautious investor base continue to be key challenges for the asset class. The TIPS index posted a second negative monthly return of -0.34% for the month, bringing YTD returns to 1.92%.
For the inflation data, the June CPI release was slightly higher than market expectations, with headline at 0.10% MoM and core at 0.44% MoM.  The composition of the report was more encouraging, as the Used Cars category contributed 15bps to the core print and falling private Manheim series argue for a reversal of recent gains to disinflationary pressures going forward once you incorporate lags in the data. More importantly, the Q1 slowdown in shelter categories was sustained in May, with rent at 0.49% and OER 0.52%, compared to the winter monthly trend of 0.7-0.8%, consistent with slowing growth in new rental pricing. Powell’s closely watched super-core category rebounded from 0.11% in April to 0.24% in May,  a mild recovery in the monthly run rate but clearly also showing cooling with the 3 month run rates around 3% , compared with 12 month run rates of 4.5%.  
For Fed policy,  the June FOMC meeting saw the policy rate unchanged  for the first time since they began the hiking cycle in March 2022. The June “skip” allows them time to assess incoming data and the impact of credit tightening on economic activity. Any pause should not be interpreted as the peak terminal, however, as the updated Fed dot plot (2 more rate hikes for 2023) continues to stress data dependency and the need to do more given the tightness of the labor market and slow progress on bringing down inflation. As such, the market is currently pricing in an 90% chance of a hike in July and a peak terminal of 5.43%. 
Strategy/Outlook:
The TIPS market continues to be challenged with various headwinds in the current environment. Downside risks emanating from the evolving bank stresses and tightening credit and monetary conditions have reduced investor appetite for the asset class. Flow technicals remain negative on the year and over the last 12 months, as both ETF and mutual fund flows have continued to see outflows in the industry.  Favorable carry dynamics will also end shortly, as negative seasonals starting after August comes into the technical picture. Valuations remain on the cheaper end of the range, in particular the front end of the breakeven curve. Real rates as discusses earlier have broken out of previously defined ranges, and given the lack of FCI tightening, the market will likely try to probe how much further it can go until it proves too restrictive for financial conditions.

Abstract: Objective  To analyze the eye lens equivalent dose levels of doctors during interventional cardiology procedures and identify related influential factors. Methods  Twenty interventional specialists were selected from a cardiovascular specialty hospital. The cumulative equivalent doses to their eye lenses during operations were monitored, and equipment-related parameters (fluoroscopy time, dose area product value [DAP], and entrance skin dose [ESD]), operation types, and operators’ positions were recorded. Results  The annual equivalent doses to the eye lenses of seven doctors exceeded 20 mSv. There was a linear correlation between the weekly number of operations and the equivalent dose to the eye lens (R2=0.457, P=0.001). The mean eye lens equivalent dose per operation was 17.1 μSv, showing linear correlations with fluoroscopy time, DAP values, and ESD values (R2=0.427, 0.206, and 0.237, respectively, P<0.05). The fluoroscopy time, DAP value, ESD value, and eye lens equivalent dose during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) were significantly higher than those during coronary angiography (t=-3.226, -3.108, -3.061, and -2.667, respectively, P<0.03). Conclusion  The annual equivalent doses to the eye lens are relatively high in interventional radiologists, some of whom may have values higher than the latest dose limit (20 mSv) suggested by the International Commission on Radiological Protection. Attention should be paid to operators performing PCI, and the workload optimization is necessary in practical operations to avoid unnecessary fluoroscopy time and reduce the eye lens doses of the operators.

In the same vein, employee job performance is also critical issue bedeviling manufacturing industry like every other organisational set up. This position is premised on the fact that the manufacturing industry may face an extinction as a result of organisational inefficiency as facilitated by poor employees’ job performance. (Onyeizugbe et al., 2019), every manufacturing company wants to break even with their products in the market place, wanting it to be consumed by all. However, producing quality products and making sure that these products are always available in the market at all time and that production is not stopped or hampered by any reason (Suzaki, 1987). (Fatile et al., 2020), argued that organisations are obliged to establish and keep long-term relationships with their staff members, this includes recognizing employees' intentions to leave, and using preventive methods that forecast factors or causes, to limit them before they occur. 
	Consequently, the various forms of behaviour and attitude disposition which organisations require of its employees in order to achieve set goals depends on talent   management aspect of human resources  practices obtainable in the organisation (Nishii, Lepak & Schneider, 2008). This implies that survival of an organisation rested on employee talent management.  Interestingly, the concept of talent management has gained more ground and relevant due to evolution of corporate human resource management in today’s present work environment. Talent management remains one of the most future-oriented practices in both private and public businesses (Ganaie & Haque, 2017).  (Fatile et al., 2020), positioned that as talent remains scarce among other factors of production, there is a need to effectively manage and retain available ones in the interest of the organisation. Today, organisations now understand and appreciate the need to have the best talents, if they must survive in this hypercompetitive and increasingly complex business environment (Smith, 2020).  It also illustrates the need to fill up key positions promptly with employees whose talents were developed within the organisation (Cappelli, 2000). 
 This aims at ensuring the right job placements at the right time, in the right position for the right candidates to deliver their best and remain committed to the organisation. Though, talent management is organisation-specific, but the focus is on developing and optimizing high potentials or talents of individuals within the organisation more quickly than ever, to enhance competitiveness. Talent is one of the critical resources for organisations to attain competitive advantage and talent management will fail without top management commitment to retaining its workforce (Okeke & Dunkwu., 2019). Effective talent management endears talented employees to an organisation as employees begin to see themselves as part of the organisation, add value to the organisation and remain glued to it (Faruna, 2018). The author further stressed that the  essence is  to  ensure employees remain professional at all times in their business practices, serve meritoriously, have the right people made up of seasoned professionals, who have excelled in their various professions, possessing the requisite integrity, skills and experience. 
      Essentially, talent management signifies comprehensive and integrated human resource practices with the goal of attracting and retaining the right individuals, for the right positions, at the right time (Sajeda, 2017). Thus Integrated talent management strategies are the combinations of series of human resources management practices of maintaining and retaining employee for a better job performance. These strategies according to Hazem (2018) include, recruiting, retaining and developing the most talented and superior employees.

Similarly, the issue of employee performance is a significant challenge affecting the manufacturing sector, just as it impacts other organizational environments. This concern is rooted in the belief that the manufacturing sector could potentially decline due to organizational inefficiency driven by subpar performance of its workers. Onyeizugbe and colleagues (2019) highlight that manufacturing firms aim to achieve market zenith with their offerings, desiring widespread consumer acceptance. However, the emphasis is on delivering high-quality products, ensuring their constant market availability, and preventing any obstacles to continuous production (Suzaki, 1987). Fatile and others (2020) contend that it is imperative for organizations to cultivate and maintain enduring relationships with their employees. This involves identifying potential intentions among employees to leave and implementing strategies that predict and mitigate these motivations before they materialize.

The expected behaviors and attitudes from employees that organizations rely on to meet their objectives are closely linked to how well they manage talent, as reflected in their human resources practices (Nishii, Lepak & Schneider, 2008). This suggests that organizational longevity hinges on effective talent management. Interestingly, the significance of talent management has become more pronounced with the evolution of corporate human resource management in the current professional landscape. It is now recognized as one of the forward-thinking practices in both the public and private sectors (Ganaie & Haque, 2017). Fatile and colleagues (2020) emphasize that since talent is a rare commodity among production factors, its proper management and retention is crucial for organizational success. In today's intensely competitive and complex business realm, companies increasingly acknowledge the necessity of securing top talent to remain viable (Smith, 2020). This entails promptly filling pivotal roles with internally developed talent (Cappelli, 2000).

The objective is to ensure optimal job placements promptly and accurately, positioning the right individuals to perform excellently and stay loyal to the organization. While talent management strategies can vary by organization, the overarching aim is to identify and cultivate the potentials of individuals more rapidly than before, boosting competitive edge. Talent represents a pivotal asset for organizations seeking a competitive advantage, and without the staunch support from top management for workforce retention, talent management initiatives may falter (Okeke & Dunkwu, 2019). Successful talent management makes employees feel integral to the organization, encouraging them to contribute value and remain dedicated (Faruna, 2018). The author also underscored the importance of ensuring that employees consistently adhere to professional standards in their practices, bringing together a team of distinguished professionals marked by exceptional integrity, skills, and experience.

In essence, talent management encompasses a holistic and integrated approach to human resources aimed at drawing in and keeping the right people in suitable roles at the appropriate times (Sajeda, 2017). Therefore, integrated talent management strategies combine various human resource management practices focused on sustaining and improving employee performance. According to Hazem (2018), these strategies involve recruiting, retaining, and fostering the development of top-tier and talented staff.

The strategy also refers to the critical corporate function where the company strives to have the best talent, closing all the talent gaps and managing the talent by insuring that the right person is in the right job at the right time to achieve the best possible results (Hezekiah, Opeyemi & Oluwatunmise, 2022). Keeping in view  various strategies and  indices of  talent management as put forward by  different researchers, this study consider it necessary to select  integrated  talent management strategies  relevant to address the  ravaging issues of employees’ turnover intentions and poor job performance, the strategies  are: human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention,  employee health and safety management, and employee  performance appraisal.
Human resource planning is one of the major strategies of understanding the talent requirements. Employee planning is the foundation of staffing; hence, the process that identifies current and future human resources needs for an organisation to achieve its goals (Armstrong, 2006). Wheeler (2014) says that employee planning is the first step in the talent management process and entails understanding the talent requirements and aligning them with the organisational goals as well as the specific service delivery environment in which the public sector department functions. According to Akinremi and Adedeji (2019), successful organisations forecast the supply and demand of their skills according to their skills requirements and ensure that top performing employees are retained in the organisation.
Another important strategy of integrated talent management is, employee development, i.e. provision of training and development in public and private organisations (career development, on /off the Job training, seminar, workshop, orientation and mentoring).  Kim (2014) emphasized how organisations should develop its technical talent professionals who must be trained or certified to perform their roles successfully. It is also a set of systematic and planned activities designed by an organisation to provide its members with the opportunities to learn necessary skills to meet current and future demands of work (Ogbeta, Nzewi & Chiekezie, 2015). Participation in staff development programmes by an employee is to begin immediately as a person is employed and should continue throughout a person’s career (Werner & Desimone, 2011). They further opined that objective of employee resources development in organisation like manufacturing industries is to increase the skills and knowledge of the workers. Employee development no doubt adds value to organisations in terms of increased productivity, morale and greater organisational efficiency (Rashid & Ayoode, 2020). 
 Employee retention is also a very crucial integrated talent management strategy. This strategy can simply be put as the policies and plans organisations have in place and follow to satisfy the diverse needs of employees and create an environment those employees to stay in the organisation (David, 2008). Financial and non-financial rewards policies, such remuneration, compensation, recognition, promotion and fringe, benefit, supervisors’ supports, etc. are commonly retention strategies for controlling employees’ turnover intentions and job performance. Employee retention can be represented by a simple statistic (for example, a retention rate of 80% usually indicates that an organisation kept 80% of its employees in a given period) (Smith, 2020).

This approach also signifies a crucial business operation where the enterprise aspires to secure optimal talent, bridging any talent deficiencies and effectively managing talent to ensure the placement of the correct individual in the suitable role at the opportune moment for the highest achievable outcomes (Hezekiah, Opeyemi & Oluwatunmise, 2022). Taking into account various methodologies and measures of talent management proposed by different scholars, this investigation deems it vital to adopt comprehensive talent management techniques aimed at confronting the pressing challenges related to employees' inclinations towards leaving and substandard job performance. The identified strategies include: strategic human resource planning, recruitment and selection, development of employees, retention strategies, management of employee health and safety, and appraisal of employee performance.

Strategic human resource planning stands as a pivotal strategy in discerning talent requisites. It lays the groundwork for staffing by identifying present and forthcoming human resource requirements that an organization must meet to reach its objectives (Armstrong, 2006). Wheeler (2014) mentions that employee planning is the initial phase in talent management, involving the understanding of talent needs and their alignment with organizational objectives and the specific operational context of the public sector entity. Akinremi and Adedeji (2019) note that successful entities project the supply and demand for their talent based on skill needs, ensuring the retention of high-performing employees within the organization.

A key facet of comprehensive talent management includes employee development, encompassing training and advancement opportunities in both public and private sectors (such as career advancement, on-the-job and off-the-job training, seminars, workshops, induction, and mentorship). Kim (2014) highlighted the importance of nurturing an organization's technical talent, who must receive adequate training or certification to excel in their roles. It also involves a sequence of organized and deliberate actions crafted by an organization to offer its members the chance to acquire the skills required for current and future job demands (Ogbeta, Nzewi & Chiekezie, 2015). The engagement of an employee in development programs should commence upon employment and persist throughout their career (Werner & Desimone, 2011). They also argued that the goal of resource advancement in organizations, such as manufacturing firms, is to enhance workers' skills and knowledge, undeniably contributing value to organizations in terms of productivity, morale, and overall efficiency (Rashid & Ayoode, 2020).

Employee retention is an equally vital strategy within integrated talent management. This strategy encompasses the approaches and initiatives that organizations implement and adhere to in order to meet the varied needs of employees and foster an environment that encourages them to remain with the organization (David, 2008). The utilization of both financial and non-financial rewards, such as salary, incentives, acknowledgment, promotion and additional benefits, support from supervisors, among others, are typical retention methods aimed at curbing employees' tendencies to leave and enhancing job performance. The concept of employee retention can be illustrated through a basic metric (for instance, maintaining 80% of its workforce within a specific timeframe is indicative of an organization's retention success) (Smith, 2020).

The author explained further that,  the rate of retention is the inverse of the rate of employee turnover and expectedly if a relatively high number of employees stayed at post within a specified period then the retention rate is high and the turnover rate is low i.e. (Retention rate = 1/turnover rate). Retaining employees is an important goal of every organisation. It helps to reduce wastage in terms of the time, effort and money spent in hiring and training new employees and integrating them into the organisation (Griffeth & Hom, 2001). Retaining all the employees may not be the desire of every business. Most of the organisations are concerned with retaining the high performers, those who possess key skill and knowledge needed to run the organisation and those who are difficult to be replaced (Ogbeta, et. at, 2015). 
More so, employee health and safety management as part of integrated talent management strategies depict general state of physical, mental, and emotional well-being of an employee (Amponsah-Tawiah & Dartey-Baah, 2011). Organisation like manufacturing industry is expected to comply with the Nigerian labour acts embedded under occupational safety and health (Ngwama, 2016). This is to ensure that, the industry takes into consideration health and safety precaution measures against organisational work hazard (Ngwama, 2016). This is important because, healthy worker is the one who is free from illness, injury, mental and emotional problems that may impair his normal work activity or routine (Dwomoh, Owusu& Addo, 2013). Onoh- Linus (2021) put it more succinctly that an organisation where employees within feel that management ‘cares’ for them, there is an indication of positive management of occupational health and safety system and as such results in safer working practices and also have positive impact on employee job performance. Positive or greater records of these outcomes support the ability of the employee to perform very well on the job for the organisation to achieve its goals (Adedayo, 2017). Thus, employee health and safety should inform policy statement covering circumstance leading to employee turnover and unconditional service withdrawal occasioned by injury, sickness and death (Beth, 2018).
Still on talent management strategy, employee performance appraisal is a strategy worth of note in this study.  According Onwuka, Ugwu and Kekeocha (2020), the key rationale to undertake performance appraisal is to gather essential information about employees for decision making. The authors further stressed that it determines employee performance, assists to communicate any areas of improvement to employees and helps the management to come up with a plan of ensuring good relations between supervisors and employees for enhanced organisational performance. This encourages employees to understand how their performance is contributing to the public sector department, they are committed to stay in the organisation (Linah, 2018). In his own views, Bello (2019) submitted that globally, diverse performance evaluation practices are employed depending on business, human resources cadre and corporation cultures. Performance appraisal has been integrated by organisations in diverse sectors in an attempt to strive and continue to exist in a global competitive economy (Onwuka et. al., 2020). Therefore, in any organisation, human capital is the most important asset that can be relied on to attain competitive advantage.

The writer goes on to state that the retention rate is directly opposed to the employee turnover rate, meaning that if a considerable number of employees remain within the company over a specific timeframe, then the retention rate is deemed high, conversely making the turnover rate low; put simply, (Retention rate = 1 / turnover rate). Keeping employees within the company is a critical aim for every business as it helps minimize losses related to the expenditure of time, effort, and finances involved in the recruitment and training of new staff, and their subsequent assimilation into the corporate environment (Griffeth & Hom, 2001). However, not all businesses aspire to retain every employee. Many are primarily focused on keeping high-performing individuals, those with essential skills and knowledge crucial for the company's operation, and those challenging to replace (Ogbeta, et al., 2015).

Additionally, the management of employee health and safety, as an element of comprehensive talent management strategies, reflects the overall physical, mental, and emotional wellness of workers (Amponsah-Tawiah & Dartey-Baah, 2011). Industries, such as manufacturing, are expected to adhere to the regulations outlined in the Nigerian labour laws concerning occupational safety and health practices (Ngwama, 2016). This adherence aims to ensure industries consider preventative measures against workplace hazards (Ngwama, 2016). This aspect is vital because a healthy employee is one who is devoid of any illness, injury, and psychological issues that could hinder their normal work routines or activities (Dwomoh, Owusu & Addo, 2013). Onoh-Linus (2021) clarified that in an organization where employees feel valued and cared for by management, there tends to be a positive implementation of occupational health and safety systems, leading to safer work practices and a positive impact on job performance. A higher frequency of these positive outcomes enhances the employee's ability to perform effectively, helping the organization to reach its objectives (Adedayo, 2017). Consequently, employee health and safety considerations should guide policies addressing factors that lead to employee turnover, including involuntary departures due to injury, illness, and mortality (Beth, 2018).

Regarding talent management strategy, the employee performance appraisal is another key strategy highlighted in this discourse. According to Onwuka, Ugwu, and Kekeocha (2020), the primary purpose of conducting performance appraisals is to collect imperative data concerning employees for decision-making processes. The authors emphasize that such assessments determine employee performance levels, facilitate communication on areas requiring improvement, and aid management in fostering positive relationships between supervisors and their subordinates for improved organizational performance. This process motivates employees by showing them how their contributions propel the public sector department forward, encouraging their continued association with the organization (Linah, 2018). Bello (2019) points out that across the globe, performance evaluation practices vary in accordance with business needs, human resource structures, and organizational cultures. Performance appraisals have been adopted by companies across various sectors in an effort to thrive and sustain in the globally competitive market (Onwuka et al., 2020). Thus, in any business entity, human capital stands as the most significant asset for securing a competitive edge.

However, the extent of the influence of selected different strategies of talent management on employee turnover intention and job performance still remains cloudy (Holden &Vaiman, 2013). This necessitate a study that will unveil the in-depth of empirical knowledge of how the strategies can be applied to resolve employee poor job performance and their frequent organisational exit resulting from their perceived turnover intentions (Yang, Wan& Fu, 2012). In order to achieve this aim, manufacturing industries in the South West Nigeria will be identified and selected as a case study. The justification for the choice  of manufacturing industries was based on the acknowledgement of the importance of the industry to the nation’s economy and the necessity of its services and products to the entire people of South West geo-political zones in particular, and the entire Nigerians in general.  Hence, this study, influence of integrated talent management strategies (human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention,  employee health and safety management, and employee  performance appraisal) on employees’ turnover intentions and job performance in Manufacturing industries in  South -West Nigeria.

Despite the various strategies of talent management being implemented, the level to which these strategies affect employee turnover intentions and job performance remains uncertain (Holden & Vaiman, 2013). This uncertainty underlines the need for comprehensive research to uncover empirical insights on how these strategies can be effectively utilized to address issues of poor job performance and frequent organizational departures due to perceived turnover intentions among employees (Yang, Wan & Fu, 2012). With this goal in mind, manufacturing industries located in South West Nigeria will be pinpointed and chosen for an in-depth case study. The rationale behind selecting manufacturing industries stems from recognizing the crucial role this sector plays in bolstering the nation's economy and the essential nature of its services and products to the populace of the South West geopolitical zones specifically, and to Nigerians at large. Therefore, this research aims to explore the impact of holistic talent management strategies (including strategic human resource planning, recruitment and selection, development of employees, employee retention strategies, management of employee health and safety, and performance appraisal of employees) on the turnover intentions and job performance of employees within the manufacturing sector in South West Nigeria.

The state of economic downfall in Nigeria has contributed to negatively to the quality of work life of an ordinary government worker in Nigeria and this has posed several challenges on retention and overall performance of employees in many work organisations  particularly in the manufacturing industry (James & Mathew, 2020).
In the manufacturing industry for instance, there have been incidences where the employees are resigning and jumping from one company to another, which results in high cost of undertaking frequent recruitments, training sessions and loss of valuable time to focus on customers (Benson, 2020). 
The manufacturing industry in Southwest Nigeria is facing challenges in terms of employee retention and performance. Despite being a vital sector for economic growth and development, the industry is experiencing high turnover rates and suboptimal employee performance (Bikefe & Daniel, 2022). This raises concerns about the long-term sustainability and competitiveness of manufacturing companies in the region. The manufacturing industry in Southwest Nigeria is grappling with high employee turnover rates, resulting in significant costs for companies and hindering their ability to maintain a skilled and experienced workforce (Bikefe & Daniel, 2022). Furthermore, the manufacturing in southwest Nigeria is facing the challenges in maintaining high levels of employee performance.
Talent management strategies in manufacturing companies are poor and rife with unethical behaviours, such as selection bias, management preferences, Federal character syndrome, influences of ethnicity and social class, selection discrimination, favouritism, and godfather syndrome (Fajana, 2009). For instance, despite the importance of effective human resource planning in supporting talent management strategies, there are gaps, challenges, and shortcomings within the manufacturing industry in South West Nigeria. Okonkwo et al. (2022) claim that many firms, particularly those in the private sector, have given human resource planning—a crucial management function—less priority. Even the so-called large companies in the private sector lack well-articulated HR planning, which has serious financial repercussions for the organizations in the areas of excessive hiring, poor job performance, training, and transfers. 
Furthermore, the recruitment and selection processes employed by manufacturing companies in South West Nigeria exhibit key issues, gaps, shortcomings, and challenges. According to Ekwoaba et al. (2015), most recruitment and selection processes have elements of subjective judgement inherent in them. Furthermore, Adagbabiri et al. (2020) pointed out that inconsistent and poorly organized hiring processes in Nigeria organisations have resulted in biased decisions, selecting applicants who are not the greatest fits for the position. These negatively impact the implementation of integrated talent management strategies, leading to higher employee turnover intention and poor job performance. Thus, it is crucial to rectify the specific gaps and challenges in recruitment and selection practices to improve talent acquisition and retention within the industry.
Furthermore, within the manufacturing industry in South West Nigeria, there are gaps, challenges, and limitations in employee development practices. These shortcomings affect the successful implementation of integrated talent management strategies, contributing to increased turnover intention and reduced job performance. Emeti (2015), stated that employees in Nigerian manufacturing companies are not sufficiently compensated for their work and training practices are marked by crude and unprofessional approaches.  The author further stressed that these factors have thus contributed to employees' intention to leave and their poor performances. Therefore, it is imperative to address the specific gaps and challenges in employee development processes to foster the growth and skill enhancement of employees.

The economic downturn in Nigeria has adversely affected the quality of work life for the average government worker, leading to numerous challenges in employee retention and performance across various organizations, especially within the manufacturing sector (James & Mathew, 2020). Specifically, in the manufacturing industry, there have been incidents where employees frequently resign to join other companies, incurring substantial costs associated with continual recruitment, training, and the diversion of attention from customer service (Benson, 2020). The manufacturing sector in Southwest Nigeria is confronting significant challenges related to keeping employees and optimizing their performance. Even though this sector is crucial for economic growth and development, it suffers from high staff turnover and less-than-ideal performance levels among its employees (Bikefe & Daniel, 2022). These issues raise concerns about the sector's ability to sustain its operations and remain competitive in the long term. The high turnover has particularly impacted the industry's capacity to sustain a competent and experienced workforce, thus affecting the performance levels (Bikefe & Daniel, 2022).

The talent management practices within manufacturing companies are plagued with issues like unethical behaviors, including biases in selection, management preferences, the Federal character syndrome, the influence of ethnicity and social class, discriminatory practices, favoritism, and the prevalence of the godfather syndrome (Fajana, 2009). For example, critical aspects such as human resource planning, which supports talent management strategies, face numerous deficiencies, challenges, and shortcomings within the manufacturing industry in Southwest Nigeria. Okonkwo et al. (2022) observed that many companies, particularly in the private sector, have not prioritized human resource planning, a vital management function. This neglect, even amongst larger private sector companies, has led to significant financial consequences in terms of unnecessary hiring, subpar job performance, and inadequate training and transfers.

Moreover, the recruitment and selection methods utilized by manufacturing companies in Southwest Nigeria are fraught with major issues, gaps, shortcomings, and challenges. Ekwoaba et al. (2015) mentioned that most recruiting and selection processes are tainted by subjective judgments. At the same time, Adagbabiri et al. (2020) highlighted that inconsistent and poorly managed hiring processes in Nigerian organizations have culminated in biased decisions and the selection of candidates who are ill-suited for the roles. These deficiencies hinder the effective execution of integrated talent management strategies, resulting in increased intentions among employees to leave and decreased job performance. Hence, addressing these specific recruitment and selection issues is vital for enhancing talent acquisition and retention in the sector.

Also, within the South West Nigerian manufacturing sector, there are notable gaps, challenges, and limitations in employee development practices. These flaws hamper the effective implementation of holistic talent management strategies, contributing to heightened turnover intentions and diminished job performance. Emeti (2015) noted that employees within Nigerian manufacturing companies are inadequately rewarded for their efforts, with training practices characterized by rudimentary and unprofessional methods. These issues have consequently led to an increase in employees’ intentions to leave and a decline in their performance. Addressing the particular gaps and challenges in employee development is crucial for encouraging employee growth and skill improvement.

Furthermore, manufacturing companies in Nigeria face significant issues, gaps, challenges, and shortcomings related to employee retention strategies. The manufacturing industry in Nigeria has little opportunities for career growth, especially for entry-level and mid-level employees (Kojo et al., 2023). Thus, employees are less likely to stay with the same firm due to the lack of clear growth paths and development opportunities, which has also impacted their performance (Kojo et al., 2023). These hinders the effective execution of integrated talent management strategies, resulting in higher turnover intention and lower job performance. Thus, it is vital to rectify the specific challenges and gaps in employee retention practices to create a positive work environment and enhance employee satisfaction within the industry. 
In addition, the identified gaps, challenges, and deficiencies in employee health and safety management practices within the manufacturing industry in South West Nigeria impact the successful implementation of integrated talent management strategies. Okechukwu and Chizoba (2022), opined that the manufacturing sector in Nigeria exposes workers to potentially harmful elements like chemicals, fumes, and noise, all of which have a negative impact on their health. Inadequate measures to reduce exposure to these risks have resulted in long-term health issues, which has increased turnover intention (Okechukwu & Chizoba, 2022). Therefore, it is crucial to address the specific gaps and challenges in health and safety management practices to create a safe and healthy work environment and improve overall employee well-being.
Furthermore, the employee performance appraisal processes used by manufacturing companies in South West Nigeria exhibit key issues, gaps, challenges, and limitations. Okholi and Orhero (2020) noted that Performance appraisals in the Nigeria Manufacturing sector are been influenced by personal biases and favoritism, especially in organisations where personal relationships and connections play a significant role. This has thus resulted in unfair evaluations and demotivation among employees who feel disadvantaged. These shortcomings affect the successful implementation of integrated talent management strategies, resulting in higher turnover intention and suboptimal job performance. Therefore, it is imperative to identify and address the specific gaps and challenges in performance appraisal processes to provide employees with clearer expectations, fair evaluations, and constructive feedback. These statements of the problem provide a comprehensive overview of the challenges and gaps associated with each variable within the research topic. They highlight the specific issues that need to be addressed and form a solid foundation for the research dissertation.
Furthermore, the turnover challenges facing organisations is taking its tolls leading to loss of highly skilled staff, loss of knowledge and experience, established customer relations, and may even result in poor customer satisfaction, poor sales, and resultant possible loss of revenue and market share (David, 2018).  Essentially, it has been observed from the related studies that, various researchers have conducted studies on different talent management variables as determinants of employees’ turnover intentions and job performance at work place. Such variables include: compensation management, recruitment and selection, leadership styles, human resources planning, performance appraisal, training and development and career management, employee retention, health and safety management and the findings remain positive and were statistically significant (Wan & Syarif, 2015; Chipunza & Malo, 2017; Gareth, 2017; Harris & Williamson 2018; Onuorah et. al., 2019; Bello (2019); Onwukaet. al. 2020; Hezekiah, 2022; Adeoye & Elegunde, 2020; Debowale, 2021).

Manufacturing enterprises in Nigeria are encountering significant difficulties, gaps, and challenges in their employee retention strategies. The sector offers limited career advancement opportunities, particularly for those at entry-level and mid-level positions, leading to a high likelihood of employees leaving due to the absence of defined pathways for growth and development, subsequently affecting their performance (Kojo et al., 2023). These obstacles hinder the successful deployment of comprehensive talent management strategies, causing an increase in turnover intentions and a decline in job performance. Therefore, addressing these specific employee retention challenges is crucial to creating an attractive work environment and boosting employee satisfaction within the industry.

Moreover, the manufacturing industry in South West Nigeria faces crucial issues in employee health and safety management practices, impacting the effective implementation of integrated talent management strategies. Okechukwu and Chizoba (2022) pointed out that workers in the Nigerian manufacturing sector are often exposed to hazardous substances such as chemicals, fumes, and noise, adversely affecting their health. The lack of sufficient measures to mitigate exposure to these hazards has led to chronic health problems, contributing to an increased desire to leave among employees. Addressing these health and safety management challenges is vital for fostering a safe and healthy work setting and enhancing overall employee well-being.

In addition, the performance appraisal systems in place within South West Nigeria's manufacturing companies feature notable deficiencies, obstacles, and challenges. Okholi and Orhero (2020) observed that performance evaluations in Nigeria's manufacturing sector are frequently affected by personal biases and favoritism, particularly in organizations where personal connections significantly influence. This has led to unfair assessments and demoralization among employees who perceive themselves to be at a disadvantage. These problems obstruct the successful execution of holistic talent management strategies, elevating turnover intentions and diminished job performance. Identifying and resolving these performance appraisal issues is essential for providing employees with clear expectations, equitable evaluations, and constructive feedback, establishing a robust foundation for the research dissertation.

Moreover, the challenges associated with turnover are exerting a profound impact, leading to the loss of highly skilled staff, departure of knowledge and experience, deterioration of customer relationships, potentially resulting in decreased customer satisfaction, reduced sales, and possible declines in revenue and market share (David, 2018). An examination of related studies shows that various researchers have explored different talent management variables as determinants of employees’ turnover intentions and job performance in the workplace. These variables include compensation management, recruitment and selection, leadership styles, human resource planning, performance appraisal, training and development, career management, employee retention, and health and safety management, with the results being positive and statistically significant (Wan & Syarif, 2015; Chipunza & Malo, 2017; Gareth, 2017; Harris & Williamson, 2018; Onuorah et al., 2019; Bello (2019); Onwuka et al., 2020; Hezekiah, 2022; Adeoye & Elegunde, 2020; Debowale, 2021).

Furthermore, it has been observed from the literature reviewed for the study that researchers have dissipated much efforts to investigate the composite or relative influence of not more than two or three of the talent management variables on the problem under investigation. Hence, this inadequacy will not bring into the fore the clear picture of the relationship among integrated talent management strategies, employees’ turnover intentions and job performance.  It is in the light of the above that this study set to examine the influence of integrated talent management strategies (human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention, employee health and safety management, and employee performance appraisal) on employees’ turnover intentions and job performance in manufacturing industries in South -West Nigeria.  This is for the purpose of ascertaining the contribution of integrated talent management strategies to employees’ turnover intentions and job performance in South-West Nigeria.

The literature review conducted for this study reveals that prior research has largely concentrated on examining either the combined effect or the individual impact of a limited number of talent management variables—typically no more than two or three—on the issues being investigated. This approach falls short of providing a comprehensive understanding of how integrated talent management strategies as a whole correlate with employees' turnover intentions and job performance. Such a gap in the research underscores the lack of a detailed exploration into how various components of talent management interact and influence key organizational outcomes.

Given this gap, the current study aims to delve into the effect of a broader range of integrated talent management strategies, encompassing human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention, employee health and safety management, and employee performance appraisal, on employees' turnover intentions and job performance within the manufacturing sector in South-West Nigeria. The objective is to determine the extent to which these integrated talent management strategies collectively contribute to shaping employees' desires to stay with their employer and their overall performance at work in the region. This endeavor seeks not only to fill the noted research void but also to offer actionable insights into the efficacy of comprehensive talent management approaches in mitigating turnover intentions and enhancing job performance among employees in South-West Nigeria's manufacturing industries.

Organisational establishments are becoming more aware of importance of talent management practices in different organisations. This study will unveil the nexus of talent management and employees’ turnover intentions and job performance. This study will expose the management of manufacturing industries and other organisations to how the adopted integrated talent management strategies (human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention, employee health and safety management and employee performance appraisal) would solve the challenges of employees’ turnover and improve their job performance. Also, the findings of this study would enhance capacity of management of organisations in designing policies for talent enhancement so as to reduce the frequency of organisational exits by employees every now and then. 
The study will also be beneficial to the Government at all levels to make significant improvements on the formulation of the rules, laws and regulations, particularly, on the working relationship between company’s management, and staff to engender sustainable industrial harmony. So also, the findings of the study will guide the managements in their decision regarding employee welfare.  Furthermore, the study will serve as a guide for both researchers and academicians doing further related researches aiming at reducing employees’ turnover intentions and improving employees’ job performance in both public and private organisations. Finally, the findings of the study will add value to the field of human resource management and thereby expanding the frontiers of knowledge.

Organizational entities are increasingly recognizing the critical role of talent management practices across diverse sectors. This investigation is set to uncover the connection between talent management strategies and both employees’ turnover intentions and their job performance. It aims to enlighten the management of manufacturing industries and other entities on how the implementation of comprehensive talent management strategies—including human resource planning, recruitment and selection, employee development, employee retention, employee health and safety management, and employee performance appraisal—can address turnover challenges and bolster job performance. Moreover, the insights from this study are expected to empower organizational leaders in crafting advantageous policies focused on talent enhancement, thereby curbing the frequent exits of employees.

Additionally, this research will prove beneficial to government authorities at various levels by offering substantial improvements in the development of policies, laws, and regulations, especially concerning the relationship between company management and their staff to foster lasting industrial peace. The findings will also assist management in making informed decisions regarding employee welfare, ensuring a more supportive and productive work environment.

Furthermore, this study will act as a valuable resource for both scholars and practitioners conducting further research aimed at diminishing employees’ turnover intentions and enhancing their job performance in both public and private sectors. Finally, the contributions of this study will enrich the field of human resource management, broadening the scope of knowledge and introducing novel insights into the intricate dynamics of talent management and its impact on organizational success.

The definitions of talent differs from organisation to organisation (Romans, 2021). Hayes (2019) stated that in organisations, the term talent is used to refer to individuals possessing highly competent skills and knowledge. According to Adeyemi (2017), every organisation needs to set a standard for what it defines as talent. This knowledge and skills relate not only to the actual work, but also to other aspects of the organisation. James (2015) concurs with Haid (2012) that talent refers to certain individuals who have the skills, knowledge and attributes necessary to carry out tasks in an outstanding way. Elegbe (2020) argued that the term talent has been defined differently in literature. Generally, the term talent is defined as an aptitude, a natural endowment, a mental power or a unique gift Luna-Arocas, & Morley, (2015). According to Romans (2021), some authors define talent as individuals with characteristics that are unique while others view talent as the exceptional skills, abilities, experience, competencies and knowledge that people possess.
James and Mathew (2020) identified the critical role that leadership plays in identifying and managing talent. Fitzgerald (2017) suggested that, great leaders refer to talent as a recurring pattern of feelings, thoughts and behaviour that can be applied to the organisation productively. According to Cheese, Thomas and Craig (2008), individuals use these qualities and attributes to achieve goals in the interest of the organisation. Rueff and Stringer (2019) asserted that talent also includes developing individuals’ skill sets to solve problems. Jokotoye (2021) affirmed that talent refers to people who have the ability to make a difference to organisational performance, decision making and service delivery through immediate or long term contributions by demonstrating high level competencies. 
Hayes (2019) stated that there is a misconception that talented individuals always perform outstandingly. Kehinde (2019) argued that talent on its own will not make a person stand out, however, it is how it is developed and utilized that enables an individual to perform exceptionally. One common aspect in most definitions is that talent is inborn just like intelligence and not acquired (Elegbe, 2020).   Harris and Williamson (2018) is of the opinion that a common understanding is important of what entails talent so as to create a benchmark for making hiring, developmental and promotional decisions within the organisation. Hayes (2019) concluded that talent is used as an all-encompassing term describing the personnel that organisations need to attract, acquire, develop, promote and retain so as to achieve organisational goals and to perform competitively in the external environment. The confidence in talent and its bottom line are at the heart of talent management (Tanton, 2017).

The concept of talent varies significantly across different organizations (Romans, 2021). As Hayes (2019) notes, within the context of organizations, talent often refers to individuals who possess exceptional skills and knowledge. Adeyemi (2017) highlights the importance for each organization to establish its own criteria for defining talent, underscoring that these skills and knowledge extend beyond mere job functions to encompass various facets of the organization. Echoing this sentiment, James (2015) agrees with Haid (2012) that talent encapsulates those individuals endowed with the necessary skills, knowledge, and attributes to excel in their tasks. Elegbe (2020) points out the diverse definitions of talent present in literature, generally interpreting it as either an innate ability, a mental prowess, or a special gift according to Luna-Arocas & Morley (2015). Romans (2021) further elaborates that while some authors regard talent as a unique set of characteristics, others view it as the outstanding skills, abilities, experiences, competencies, and knowledge people possess.

The pivotal role of leadership in identifying and managing talent is underscored by James and Mathew (2020), with Fitzgerald (2017) suggesting that excellent leaders perceive talent as a pattern of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that can be productively harnessed for organizational benefit. Cheese, Thomas, and Craig (2008) emphasize that individuals employ such qualities to achieve objectives that align with organizational interests. Additionally, Rueff and Stringer (2019) suggest that talent also involves the development of skill sets to tackle problems effectively. Jokotoye (2021) defines talent as individuals capable of significantly enhancing organizational performance, decision-making, and service delivery through their competencies, whether immediately or over the long term.

However, Hayes (2019) points out a common misconception that talent invariably results in superior performance. Kehinde (2019) contests that talent alone is insufficient for exceptional performance; it is the development and application of talent that truly empowers an individual to excel. Elegbe (2020) notes that unlike skills which can be acquired, talent is often seen as an inherent trait, similar to intelligence. Harris and Williamson (2018) argue for a unified understanding of talent to inform hiring, development, and promotion decisions within an organization. Concluding, Hayes (2019) defines talent as a comprehensive term that encompasses the personnel an organization must attract, develop, and retain to meet its goals and maintain competitiveness in the marketplace. According to Tanton (2017), the belief in talent and its alignment with the organization's bottom line is central to effective talent management.

Olorunda (2021) submitted that, there is no consensus as to what the term talent management refers to in the academic world. The lack of clarity with regards to the concept of talent management often results in different perceptions arising amongst employees and management (Bayonle, 2013). Devine and Powell (2018) stated that talent management has been a trending topic for management in both the public and private sector. For some organisations, talent is an all-encompassing term which refers to all employees, whilst in other organisations, it is reworded as a skills gap (Mabika, 2016). Blass (2019) emphasized that all organisations practice talent management, however, many organisations often do not have a policy or set procedures to implement and monitor the process. Joubert (2013) argued that to formulate an effective talent management strategy, every organisation should outline the skills and competencies that entails a talented employee. This will depend directly on the organisation’s talent needs and requirements.
According to Thunnisen (2013), the term talent management varies from author to author. Bolarinwa (2015) concurs with Thunnisen (2013) and defined talent management as a proactive process which involves the identification, attraction, retention, development and effective management of a disproportionate number of a high caliber and diverse people, who can be deployed to emerging positions, with the aim of contributing meaningfully to the overall organisational performance. Temidayo (2018), stated that talent management refers to the efforts organisations assert in attracting, selecting, developing and retaining key individuals. Deborah and Jackson (2017) elaborated that the term talent management is also associated with the recruitment and selection of individuals who have the potential to adapt and succeed in the specific job functions within a minimal time frame.
Talent Management signifies comprehensive and integrated human resource practices with the goal of attracting and retaining the right individuals, for the right positions, at the right time. Talent Management as an area of focus gained currency in 1980s, when an intense need was felt for retaining talented people and curbing attrition. This was when, the companies increasingly realize the immense value of the human assets for organisational success. Different thinkers have defined talent management in many ways. Talent management was merely viewed as the management task of ensuring that right person is placed at the right job at the right time (Jackson & Schuler, 2012). Few years down the line, talent management was seen as a thoughtful and organized effort to ensure leadership continuity by encouraging individual advancement for key positions (Rothwell, 2000; Byham, 2001; Hilton, 2000 & Olsen, 2000 cited in Jokotoye, 2021). Temidayo (2018) viewed talent management as a collection of typical human resource department practices or activities like recruitment, selection, employee development, succession management and career management. As per Joubert (2017) focus of talent management is on identification of the best and the brightest people who can deal with complexities.
Gardner, (2017) identified talent management as a collection of human resource practices like sourcing, selection, employee development and retention. Talent management was taken for identifying key positions which have the potential to differentially impact the competitive advantage of the firm (Cairns, 2019). In a holistic view, Ulrich (2016) defined talent management as identifying individuals having the knowledge, skills and values, who are committed to work and make a difference to organisational success. Talent management is concerned with succession planning or human resource planning i.e. the job flow of employees within an organisation (Kukano, 2019).

Olorunda (2021) pointed out the academic world hasn't reached a consensus on a unified definition of talent management, leading to various interpretations among employees and management (Bayonle, 2013). The concept has become a pervasive subject of interest across both public and private sectors, as mentioned by Devine and Powell (2018). Mabika (2016) noted that in some organizations, 'talent' is a comprehensive term referring to all staff members, whereas in others, it signifies a skills shortage. Blass (2019) highlighted that while all organizations engage in talent management, many lack a formal policy or established practices to guide and evaluate the process adequately. Joubert (2013) recommended that an organization should clearly delineate the skills and competencies characteristic of a 'talented' employee, tailoring this definition to its unique talent needs and objectives.

Echoing the variability in definitions, Thunnisen (2013) observed that interpretations of talent management differ widely among scholars. Bolarinwa (2015) expanded on this by describing talent management as a proactive endeavor focused on identifying, attracting, developing, and managing a select group of high-quality and diverse personnel. These individuals are primed for future pivotal roles, with the intention of significantly contributing to organizational success. Temidayo (2018) further defined it as organizational efforts directed toward the attraction, selection, development, and retention of key personnel. Deborah and Jackson (2017) associated talent management with the processes of recruiting and selecting individuals capable of quickly adapting to and excelling in specific job roles.

Talent management incorporates comprehensive and integrated human resource practices aimed at sourcing and keeping the right individuals in appropriate positions at the ideal time. Originating in the 1980s amid a push to retain talent and minimize turnover, organizations began to acknowledge their human assets' substantial value toward achieving success. According to Jackson & Schuler (2012), talent management initially was seen solely as the process of placing the right person in the right job at the correct time. In the ensuing years, it evolved to include a deliberate effort to ensure leadership continuity and facilitate personal growth for critical roles, as discussed by Rothwell (2000) and others cited in Jokotoye (2021). Temidayo (2018) described it as encompassing typical HR department functions like recruitment, selection, development, succession, and career management. Joubert (2017) stressed its focus on identifying highly capable individuals who can navigate complex challenges effectively.

Gardner (2017) identified it as encompassing human resource practices such as talent sourcing, selection, development, and retention. Cairns (2019) viewed it as essential for identifying key roles that significantly influence an organization's competitive advantage. From a comprehensive perspective, Ulrich (2016) defined it as the process of pinpointing individuals with the necessary knowledge, skills, and values committed to working and contributing to the organization's success. Lastly, talent management has been linked with succession planning or human resource planning, involving the strategic movement of employees within an organization (Kukano, 2019).

In their own view Collings & Mellahi (2019) defined talent management as activities and processes involving systematic identification of key positions in the organisation which contribute to the organisation’s sustainable competitive advantage, developing a talent pool of high potential and high performing incumbents to fill these roles, and the development of these incumbents to ensure their continued commitment to the organisation.
Zaman (2021) defines talent management as managing the entire employee lifecycle from attracting and hiring to promoting and finding a successor upon retirement. It also includes identification of the key gaps between the talent in place and the talent required to drive business success. Devine and Powell (2018) took a narrow view of talent in their study, identified four categories of employees in any organisation, namely, champions, professionals, semi-professionals and amateurs. Professionals, with their extensive quantitative skills and semi-professionals like marketing analysts who apply analytics to business problems are most crucial to business success, because of their scarce and not easily replaceable talent. Professionals and semi-professionals are believed to be most difficult to attract, develop, engage and retain because of the value they bring to organisation (Fapohunda, 2015). They need to be managed differently from other employees. This view links talent management to irreplaceable skills which are critical to organisational success. Some practitioners describe talent management as a key component in effective succession planning while others state talent management an attempt to make all the employees work at the top of their potential (Sanjay, 2017). In conclusion, it can be inferred that talent management encompasses a long list of activity revolving around creation of talent pool. It is the process which includes talent gap analysis, talent identification, talent acquisition, talent development, talent deployment, performance management, talent investigation, talent retention and career planning and succession management of high potential employees with skills which are important to the organisation.

Collings and Mellahi (2019) present talent management as a series of activities and processes that strategically identify key positions contributing to an organization's sustainable competitive edge. It involves creating a pool of high potential and high performing individuals ready to fill these roles, coupled with their ongoing development to foster their commitment to the organization.

Zaman (2021) views talent management as overseeing the entire employee lifecycle, encompassing the attraction and hiring of individuals, their promotion, and the appointment of their successors upon retirement. This definition extends to spotting the critical gaps between the existing talent and the talent essential for driving business success.

Devine and Powell (2018) offer a more focused perspective on talent, categorizing employees within any organization into champions, professionals, semi-professionals, and amateurs. They underscore the importance of professionals, known for their significant quantitative skills, and semi-professionals like marketing analysts who apply analytics to address business problems. These groups are seen as pivotal to business success due to their rare and irreplaceable expertise. Given their exceptional value to the organization, professionals and semi-professionals present a significant challenge in terms of attraction, development, engagement, and retention, necessitating distinct management approaches from the rest of the workforce.

From another perspective, some practitioners regard talent management as an integral part of successful succession planning. In contrast, others view it as an effort to maximize the potential of all employees (Sanjay, 2017). 

In summarizing these viewpoints, it's evident that talent management comprises a comprehensive suite of activities focused on developing a talent reservoir. The process involves talent gap analysis, identification, acquisition, development, deployment, performance management, examination, retention, career planning, and succession management for high-potential employees possessing skills crucial to the organization’s success.

According to Mohammed (2015) talent Management serves quite a purpose when it comes to attracting, and recruiting future employees, talented employees are considered as strategic assets that have enough potential to produce and capture value and execute business strategies. Sharma & Raval (2016) put talent management apparently in different aspects, which are as follows:
1. Globalization, as it provides a wider scope of possibilities for job seekers around the globe. One can know the opportunities available in any part of the world easily.
2. Increasing competition, which necessitated talent management to ensure a consistently good performance, thus, making companies put in all effort possible to hire, train, and retain the best talent available within the field of operation.
3. Increasing knowledge, to retain those who are talented and possess the ability to adapt to new technologies and knowledge, that are growing at a very fast pace. Talent management is very important in such case because it brings together significant human resources and management initiatives. Usually, organisations that adopt a talent management approach would focus on coordinating and integrating the following Sharma & Raval (2016):
A-Recruitment, to ensure that the right people are attracted to the organisation at the right time.
B-Retention, to ensure the implementation and development of practices that reward and support employees.
C-Employee development, to ensure continuous informal and formal learning and development processes.
D-Leadership and “high-potential employee” development, to ensure the availability of specific development programs for current and future leaders.
E-Performance management, to ensure the availability of specific processes that could improve and support performance, including feedback and measurement.
F-Workforce planning, to ensure the availability of plans for business and general changes, including the older staff as well as existing and future shortage in skills;
G-Culture, which ensures the development of a positive, progressive, and high performance “way of operating.”

Mohammed (2015) highlights the significance of talent management in drawing and recruiting future employees, portraying talented individuals as strategic assets with the potential to generate value and execute business strategies. Sharma & Raval (2016) further break down talent management into several key aspects, underscoring its importance across various organizational functions:

1. **Globalization:** This provides a broad spectrum of opportunities for job seekers globally, enabling individuals to discover vacancies in any part of the world effortlessly.

2. **Increasing Competition:** There's a pressing need for talent management to ensure consistent outstanding performance. This competition drives organizations to exert comprehensive effort in hiring, training, and keeping the best talent within their operational sphere.

3. **Rapid Knowledge Expansion:** Retaining individuals talented in assimilating new technologies and knowledge, which advance swiftly, is crucial. Talent management plays a pivotal role here by synchronizing substantial human resource and management endeavors. Organizations adopting a talent management philosophy typically concentrate on harmonizing and melding the following elements, as outlined by Sharma & Raval (2016):

   A. **Recruitment:** Aims to guarantee the attraction of the appropriate candidates to the organization at the opportune time.

   B. **Retention:** Focuses on establishing and refining practices that recognize and sustain employees.
   
   C. **Employee Development:** Emphasizes ongoing informal and formal learning and development initiatives.
   
   D. **Leadership and High-potential Employee Development:** Encompasses providing specific development programs tailored for current and future leaders to assure their preparedness and efficacy.
   
   E. **Performance Management:** Aims to support and enhance performance through precise processes, including constructive feedback and performance evaluation.
   
   F. **Workforce Planning:** Concerned with the preparation for business changes and shifts, accounting for aging staff, and anticipating existing and impending skill shortages.
   
   G. **Cultural Development:** Seeks to cultivate a positive, progressive, and highly effective organizational culture, thereby fostering a "way of operating" that promotes high performance.

In essence, talent management is a multifaceted function integral to the strategic human resource framework of organizations. It not only facilitates the securing of high-caliber personnel but also ensures their development, retention, and effective contribution to organizational goals and success.

how to write theme section write-up

To write a theme section write-up, you should first identify the main themes or patterns that have emerged from the data or research. Then, describe each theme in detail, providing examples or evidence to support your analysis. Make sure to explain the significance of each theme and how it relates to the overall research question or objective. Additionally, consider organizing the themes in a logical sequence to create a coherent narrative for the reader. Finally, conclude the write-up by summarizing the key findings and implications of the identified themes.

To write a theme section write-up for the question "What are the characteristics of public health doctoral student experiences with COVID-19?" you would: 

1. Identify main themes: Start by reviewing the data gathered from public health doctoral students about their experiences with COVID-19. Identify recurring patterns, experiences, or characteristics that stand out.

2. Describe each theme: For each identified theme, provide a detailed description of what it entails. Include specific examples or quotes from the students to illustrate the theme.

3. Explain the significance: Discuss why each theme is important and how it contributes to understanding the experiences of public health doctoral students during the COVID-19 pandemic. Connect the themes to the broader context of public health education and practice.

4. Organize themes: Arrange the themes in a logical order that helps to create a cohesive narrative. Consider how the themes relate to each other and build upon one another in the context of the research question.

5. Conclude the write-up: Summarize the key findings from the themes identified and discuss their implications for public health doctoral students, education, and practice. Reflect on any broader implications for the field of public health research and policy.

---

In exploring the characteristics of public health doctoral student experiences with COVID-19, several key themes emerged from the data collected. These themes shed light on the unique challenges and perspectives of students navigating their studies during a global pandemic.

The first theme that emerged was the impact of remote learning on student engagement and academic performance. Many students expressed difficulties in adjusting to online classes and the lack of face-to-face interaction with peers and professors. One student remarked, "I miss the collaborative environment of our in-person seminars, which has affected my motivation and focus."

Another prominent theme revolved around the mental health and well-being of students during the pandemic. The stress and uncertainty of the situation took a toll on many students, with feelings of isolation and anxiety being commonly reported. A student shared, "The constant news updates about COVID-19 and the pressure to stay informed have been overwhelming, leading to increased levels of stress."

Furthermore, the theme of resilience and adaptability emerged as students described their strategies for coping with the challenges brought about by COVID-19. Many students highlighted how they had to quickly adapt to new ways of learning and conducting research, demonstrating their ability to persevere in the face of adversity. One student noted, "I have learned to be more flexible and resourceful in my approach to research, which has been a valuable skill gained during this time."

Overall, these themes provide valuable insights into the experiences of public health doctoral students during the COVID-19 pandemic. By understanding these characteristics, educators and policymakers can better support students in navigating the challenges of remote learning, prioritizing mental health, and fostering resilience in times of crisis.

---
